usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Lack of visibility into Batch job performance
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Lack of visibility into batch job performance in AWS Batch refers to insufficient monitoring and insight into how batch jobs are executing. This can lead to undetected inefficiencies, unresolved issues, and a lack of understanding of system performance, which impacts decision-making and operational effectiveness.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Inadequate Monitoring Tools Insufficient or improperly configured monitoring tools that fail to capture necessary performance data.
  • Complex Workflows Complicated job dependencies and sequences that are difficult to track without advanced tools.
  • Human Error Oversight or mismanagement in setting up effective monitoring and logging practices.
  • System Overload High volume of jobs that overwhelm existing monitoring capabilities.

Impacts

  • Delayed Issue Resolution Problems go unnoticed, leading to longer downtimes and slower response times.
  • Inefficient Resource Use Without visibility, resource allocation cannot be optimized, leading to waste.
  • Poor Decision Making Lack of data hampers the ability to make informed decisions regarding job scheduling and resource management.
  • Increased Costs Unseen inefficiencies and issues can drive up operational costs.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Inadequate Monitoring Setup A company fails to implement detailed job performance monitoring, leading to undetected job failures and increased costs over time.
  2. Complex Job Chains In a complex job sequence, a failure in an early job goes unnoticed, causing delays in downstream jobs and extending processing times.
  3. Human Oversight An administrator overlooks configuring critical alerts, resulting in a delayed response to job performance issues that escalate costs.
  4. System Overload The monitoring system is overwhelmed by a high volume of jobs, leading to gaps in visibility and inefficient job execution.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

threat.name: Unmanaged job failures and timeouts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unmanaged job failures and timeouts in AWS Batch occur when jobs fail or timeout without proper handling or notification. This can lead to incomplete data processing, prolonged downtime, and cascading failures in dependent jobs, which can severely impact business operations and service delivery.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Lack of Monitoring Inadequate monitoring systems that fail to detect or report job failures and timeouts in real-time.
  • Misconfigured Retry Policies Incorrectly configured or absent retry policies that do not adequately address failed jobs.
  • Human Error Failure to set up appropriate alerts or error-handling mechanisms.
  • Complex Dependencies Jobs with complex interdependencies that are not properly managed, leading to cascading failures.

Impacts

  • Incomplete Processing Failed or timed-out jobs can leave tasks incomplete, resulting in data inconsistency or loss.
  • Operational Delays Jobs that fail or timeout without proper management can cause significant delays in workflows.
  • Increased Costs Resources may be wasted on repeated job failures without resolution, leading to higher operational expenses.
  • Cascading Failures One failed job can trigger failures in dependent jobs, amplifying the disruption across the system.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. No Alerting on Failures A critical job fails, but due to a lack of alerting mechanisms, the issue is not detected until it has caused significant delays in the processing pipeline.
  2. Improper Retry Configuration A job consistently times out due to insufficient execution time, but the retry policy is either too aggressive or not configured, causing the job to fail repeatedly without resolution.
  3. Human Oversight An administrator fails to configure proper timeout settings, leading to jobs hanging indefinitely and blocking the queue.
  4. Dependency Mismanagement A dependent job fails, causing all subsequent jobs in the sequence to fail as well, leading to a complete halt in processing.

threat.name: Resource exhaustion due to suboptimal compute environment configuration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Resource exhaustion due to suboptimal compute environment configuration in AWS Batch occurs when the compute environment is not properly tuned, leading to inefficient resource allocation. This can result in overconsumption of compute resources, which may cause job failures, delays, or complete service disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Misconfiguration Incorrect settings in the compute environment, such as wrong instance types or insufficient scaling policies.
  • Inadequate Resource Planning Failure to properly estimate the required resources for job execution.
  • Automated Mismanagement Automated systems incorrectly scaling resources based on poor configuration or inaccurate data.
  • Human Error Errors in setting up or maintaining the compute environment.

Impacts

  • Job Failures Insufficient resources can lead to job failures and retries, increasing processing time and costs.
  • Service Downtime Overloaded resources may cause the entire batch processing service to become unavailable.
  • Increased Costs Inefficient resource usage leads to higher expenses due to unnecessary scaling or overprovisioning.
  • Performance Degradation Slower job processing times and reduced throughput due to inadequate resource allocation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Incorrect Instance Types The compute environment is configured with instance types that are either too small or too large, leading to resource bottlenecks or wastage.
  2. Poor Scaling Policies Automatic scaling is not properly configured, causing either under-provisioning, leading to job queuing, or over-provisioning, resulting in unnecessary costs.
  3. Resource Overcommitment A compute environment is overcommitted to too many jobs, causing some to fail due to lack of available resources.
  4. Human Misconfiguration An administrator mistakenly configures the environment with inadequate memory or CPU resources, leading to job failures and prolonged processing times.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Inefficient job execution order
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Inefficient Job Execution Order in AWS Batch refers to jobs being executed in a suboptimal sequence, leading to poor resource utilization, increased costs, and extended processing times. This inefficiency can result from misconfiguration, poor prioritization, or insufficient job dependency management.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Misconfiguration: Errors in setting job priorities or sequences.
  • Insider Threat: Deliberate or accidental misordering by an internal actor.
  • Automated Systems: Poorly configured scheduling algorithms.
  • Complex Dependencies: Failure to manage job dependencies correctly.

Impacts

  • Increased Costs: Longer resource usage leads to higher expenses.
  • Decreased Performance: Delayed job completion affects overall system throughput.
  • Resource Starvation: Critical jobs may be delayed by non-critical tasks.
  • Operational Disruption: Entire workflows may be disrupted.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Misconfigured Priorities: Non-critical jobs run before critical ones, delaying important tasks.
  2. Lack of Monitoring: Over time, job execution becomes inefficient, increasing costs and delays.
  3. Dependency Mismanagement: Jobs run out of order, leading to incomplete processing and wasted resources.
  4. Insider Sabotage: An employee deliberately misorders jobs to disrupt operations

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Incorrect job execution order
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Incorrect job execution order in AWS Batch refers to jobs being executed out of the intended sequence, leading to disrupted workflows, data inconsistency, and operational inefficiencies. This can occur due to misconfiguration, dependency mismanagement, or errors in job scheduling, causing significant issues in the processing pipeline.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Misconfiguration Errors in defining job sequences or dependencies within the batch configuration.
  • Dependency Mismanagement Incorrect mapping or oversight of job dependencies that leads to improper execution order.
  • Automated Systems Scheduling algorithms that incorrectly prioritize jobs.
  • Human Error Mistakes in setting up or managing the job order, leading to out-of-sequence execution.

Impacts

  • Data Inconsistency Jobs that rely on the output of prior jobs may process incomplete or incorrect data.
  • Operational Disruption Incorrect sequencing can disrupt the overall workflow, causing delays and inefficiencies.
  • Increased Costs Resources may be wasted on rerunning jobs or correcting errors caused by the incorrect order.
  • Performance Degradation The overall processing time may increase, reducing system throughput.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Misconfigured Dependencies A job meant to process data after a preprocessing step is executed first, leading to incomplete or incorrect data processing.
  2. Automated Scheduling Error An automated system prioritizes less critical jobs over urgent ones, delaying critical processing tasks.
  3. Human Misconfiguration An administrator inadvertently sets the wrong job order, causing essential jobs to be delayed until non-critical jobs are completed.
  4. Unmanaged Job Chain Jobs are set to run in parallel without proper dependency checks, leading to out-of-order execution and potential data errors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499.002 - Service Exhaustion Flood

weakness.name: CWE-1190
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1190: DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established, which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product.

weakness.name: CWE-184
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-184: Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are not allowed by policy or otherwise require other action to neutralize before additional processing takes place, but the list is incomplete, leading to resultant weaknesses. Developers often try to protect their products against malicious input by performing tests against inputs that are known to be bad, such as special characters that can invoke new commands. However, such lists often only account for the most well-known bad inputs. Attackers may be able to find other malicious inputs that were not expected by the developer, allowing them to bypass the intended protection mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

countermeasure.name: Deploy CodeBuild projects within a VPC for network isolation
countermeasure.desc: Deploy AWS CodeBuild projects within a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) to ensure that build environments are isolated from external networks, thereby reducing exposure to external threats. Configure your VPC with appropriate security groups and network access control lists (ACLs) to control inbound and outbound traffic to the build environments. This setup ensures that only authorized internal resources can communicate with the CodeBuild environment, enhancing the security of the build process. Additionally, leverage VPC endpoints for secure access to AWS services without traversing the public internet. Implementing this control helps safeguard your build environments against unauthorized access and network-based attacks.

reference.name: Use AWS CodeBuild with Amazon Virtual Private Cloud

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-22 Architecture and Provisioning for Name/address Resolution Service

countermeasure.name: Encrypt build artifacts at rest in S3
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all build artifacts generated by AWS CodeBuild are stored in Amazon S3 with encryption enabled at rest. This prevents unauthorized access to sensitive data by protecting the artifacts using AWS-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3) or customer-managed keys (SSE-KMS). To implement this control, configure the S3 bucket that stores your build artifacts to enable server-side encryption (SSE) by default. Review and validate that all existing and new artifacts are encrypted at rest. This practice helps maintain the confidentiality and integrity of your build outputs, mitigating the risk of data breaches.

reference.name: Data encryption

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Enforce strict input validation in build scripts
countermeasure.desc: Implement strict validation of all inputs used within AWS CodeBuild scripts to prevent code injection attacks. Ensure that any parameters, environment variables, or external data consumed by build scripts are thoroughly validated for correctness, format, and security. Incorporate validation checks within the build scripts to sanitize inputs, rejecting any malformed or potentially malicious data before it is processed. Use allowlists, regular expressions, and secure coding practices to further reduce the risk of injection vulnerabilities. This control helps maintain the integrity and security of your build process by preventing unauthorized code execution.

reference.name: Security in AWS CodeBuild

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Regularly update build environments with latest patches and software versions
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS CodeBuild environments are consistently updated with the latest security patches and software versions. This includes regularly reviewing and applying updates to the underlying operating systems, libraries, and dependencies used within your build environments. Automate the update process where possible by utilizing AWS services such as AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager or incorporating patching steps into your CI/CD pipeline. Regularly verify that your build environments are up-to-date to minimize vulnerabilities and protect against potential security threats. Maintaining current software versions is critical for the security and stability of your build processes.

reference.name: Docker images provided by CodeBuild

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to S3 buckets for build artifacts
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that access to S3 buckets storing AWS CodeBuild artifacts is tightly controlled by implementing strict permissions. Configure bucket policies and IAM roles to allow access only to authorized users and services that require it. Utilize the principle of least privilege by granting the minimum necessary permissions for accessing, modifying, or managing the build artifacts. Additionally, consider enabling logging and monitoring of access to these S3 buckets using AWS CloudTrail and Amazon S3 access logs to detect any unauthorized access attempts. Proper access control ensures the confidentiality and integrity of your build artifacts.

reference.name: Security in AWS CodeBuild

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Sanitize build logs to remove sensitive data
countermeasure.desc: Implement log sanitization processes within AWS CodeBuild to ensure that any sensitive data, such as credentials, API keys, or personally identifiable information (PII), is removed or obfuscated before logs are stored or shared. This can be achieved by incorporating log filtering mechanisms in your build scripts or using custom logging configurations that exclude sensitive information. Regularly audit and review build logs to identify and address any inadvertent exposure of sensitive data. By sanitizing logs, you protect sensitive information from unauthorized access and reduce the risk of data leakage.

reference.name: Help protect sensitive log data with masking

countermeasure.name: Use approved and hardened build images
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that only approved and security-hardened build images are used in AWS CodeBuild projects. Maintain a curated list of build images that have been vetted for security vulnerabilities and are configured according to your organization's security standards. Regularly update these images to include the latest security patches and remove outdated or vulnerable ones. Enforce the use of these approved images by restricting the selection of build environments in your CodeBuild project configurations. This control helps minimize the risk of executing malicious scripts and enhances the overall security of your build process.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Sensitive data in logs
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data in logs occurs when confidential information, such as credentials or personal data, is inadvertently recorded in AWS CodeBuild logs. This can lead to unauthorized access if the logs are improperly secured or accessed by unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, unauthorized users, or external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Accessing logs that contain sensitive data.
    • Exploiting insufficient log sanitization processes to retrieve confidential information.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information leading to potential data leaks or identity theft.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust and credibility if sensitive data is exposed.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of data protection regulations, possibly resulting in legal penalties and fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Access: An attacker gains access to CodeBuild logs and extracts exposed API keys or credentials, which they then use to compromise other systems.
  2. Internal Data Leak: A developer inadvertently logs sensitive customer information, which is later accessed by an unauthorized internal user, leading to a data breach.
  3. Compliance Breach: Logs containing personal data are accessed without proper controls, violating data protection laws and resulting in regulatory action.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Insufficient network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insufficient network isolation in AWS CodeBuild occurs when the build environment is not properly segregated from other network resources. This lack of isolation exposes the build environment to potential external threats, allowing unauthorized access, data leakage, or interference with build processes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised internal systems, or malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of network misconfigurations to gain access to the build environment.
    • Lateral movement from other compromised resources within the same network.

Impacts

  • Security Breach: Unauthorized access to the build environment, leading to potential data theft or code tampering.
  • Operational Disruption: Interference with build processes, potentially resulting in failed builds or deployment of compromised code.
  • Compliance Risks: Non-compliance with security standards requiring network segmentation, possibly leading to regulatory fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. External Attack: An attacker exploits an unprotected network segment to gain access to CodeBuild and injects malicious code into the build pipeline.
  2. Lateral Movement: A compromised server within the same network is used to access and tamper with the build environment due to lack of network segmentation.
  3. Data Exfiltration: An attacker intercepts sensitive data transmitted between the build environment and other resources due to inadequate network isolation.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Compromised build environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A compromised build environment occurs when an attacker gains unauthorized access to the infrastructure or resources used by AWS CodeBuild. This can result in the manipulation of the build process, introduction of malicious code, or exposure of sensitive data. A compromised build environment undermines the security of the entire CI/CD pipeline and can lead to severe downstream impacts on deployed applications.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised third-party tools.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in the build environment or associated infrastructure.
    • Unauthorized access due to weak security controls or misconfigurations in the build environment.

Impacts

  • Integrity Loss: Unauthorized modifications to the build process or outputs, leading to the deployment of compromised or malicious software.
  • Data Exposure: Leakage of sensitive information, including source code, credentials, and configuration files.
  • Operational Disruption: Interruption or sabotage of the build process, causing delays or deployment of flawed applications.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Infrastructure Exploit: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the underlying infrastructure hosting the build environment, gaining control over the build process and inserting malicious code into the final product.
  2. Misconfiguration Abuse: Due to a misconfiguration, an unauthorized user gains access to the build environment, modifies build scripts, and causes the deployment of compromised software.
  3. Third-Party Tool Compromise: A third-party tool integrated into the build environment is compromised, allowing an attacker to manipulate the build process or steal sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain

threat.name: Code injection via build scripts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Code injection via build scripts occurs when an attacker or unauthorized user introduces malicious code into the build scripts used by AWS CodeBuild. This malicious code can then be executed during the build process, potentially compromising the integrity of the build, leaking sensitive data, or introducing vulnerabilities into the final software product.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised CI/CD systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Inserting malicious code directly into build scripts or configurations.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in third-party dependencies or plugins used in the build process.

Impacts

  • Compromised Software Integrity: Malicious code could be embedded in the final software product, leading to security vulnerabilities or backdoors.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive information might be extracted and sent to unauthorized parties during the build process.
  • Operational Disruption: The build process could be sabotaged, resulting in failed builds or deployment of insecure code.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Script Manipulation: An attacker gains access to the build script repository and injects malicious code that exfiltrates sensitive data during the build process, which is then sent to an external server.
  2. Third-Party Dependency Exploit: A malicious actor exploits a vulnerability in a third-party library or plugin integrated into the build script, leading to the execution of unauthorized code during the build.
  3. Insider Attack: A disgruntled employee inserts malicious code into the build scripts, which, once deployed, opens a backdoor in the application for future exploitation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Unauthorized access to build artifacts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access to build artifacts occurs when individuals or entities gain access to the files, binaries, or other outputs generated by AWS CodeBuild without proper authorization. This can lead to the exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized code changes, or distribution of compromised software.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, unauthorized internal users, or compromised build systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting misconfigured S3 bucket permissions where build artifacts are stored.
    • Gaining access through over-permissioned IAM roles associated with the build environment.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive or proprietary code and data contained in build artifacts.
  • Operational Risk: Deployment of compromised or altered software, leading to potential security vulnerabilities.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust if compromised artifacts are distributed.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Misconfigured S3 Bucket: An attacker exploits a publicly accessible S3 bucket containing build artifacts, downloads the artifacts, and discovers sensitive information or injects malicious code.
  2. Internal Misuse: An insider with excessive permissions accesses build artifacts and modifies them, leading to the deployment of unauthorized code in a production environment.
  3. Artifact Tampering: An attacker gains access to artifacts stored in an insecure location, alters the files, and these compromised files are later deployed, resulting in a security breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1500 - Compile After Delivery

component.name: AWS Direct Connect
component.desc: AWS Direct Connect service used to ingest data to the cloud.

weakness.name: CWE-15
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-15: External Control of System or Configuration Setting One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user. Allowing external control of system settings can disrupt service or cause an application to behave in unexpected, and potentially malicious ways.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-942
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-942: Permissive Cross-domain Policy with Untrusted Domains The product uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted.

countermeasure.name: Automate secure configuration management
countermeasure.desc:
Eliminate manual errors and detect drift by managing every Direct Connect objectconnections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associationsthrough vetted infrastructure-as-code (IaC) pipelines and continuous compliance checks:

  1. define configurations in IaC
    • Use AWS CloudFormation, Terraform, or AWS CDK modules that encapsulate approved settings (BGP ASN ranges, VLAN IDs, Jumbo Frames, SiteLink = false).
    • Parameterize only what needs to vary (Region, speed); hard-code security defaults (e.g., enableSiteLink: false, mtu: 9001).
  2. enforce change control
    • Protect the IaC repo with branch protection, mandatory code-review, and automated security linting (cfn-nag, tfsec).
    • Require all Direct Connect changes to flow through the pipeline; block console or ad-hoc CLI edits with an Organizations SCP denying directconnect:* when aws:CalledViaLast cloudformation.amazonaws.com or your CI role.
  3. continuous drift detection
    • Turn on AWS Config rule directconnect-connection-config-check (custom) that compares live attributes to the IaC source of truth; mark resources NON_COMPLIANT on mismatch.
    • Trigger an EventBridge rule that opens a ticket or auto-reverts drift via an SSM automation document.
  4. version and audit
    • Tag every Direct Connect resource with the Git commit hash that provisioned it (IaCCommit=<sha>).
    • Store pipeline logs and change sets in an immutable S3 bucket for forensic review.

Automated, declarative management guarantees consistent security baselines, accelerates approved changes, and surfaces unauthorized modifications within minutes.

References

  • What is AWS Direct Connect?
  • What Is AWS Config?

reference.name: Security in AWS Direct Connect

countermeasure.name: Enforce IAM identity-based policies for AWS Direct Connect
countermeasure.desc:
Create narrowly scoped IAM policies (and, if you use AWS Organizations, complementary SCPs) so that only approved network-admin roles can perform Direct Connect management actionssuch as CreateConnection, AllocateHostedConnection, ConfirmPrivateVirtualInterface, or DeleteLag.

  • Author purpose-built roles give each network-engineering or automation role a custom policy that allows only the Direct Connect APIs it truly needs and only in approved Regions or on resources tagged Environment=prod. Example snippet:
  • {
     "Effect": "Allow",
     "Action": [
       "directconnect:CreateConnection",
       "directconnect:DeleteConnection",
       "directconnect:Describe*"
     ],
     "Resource": "*",
     "Condition": {
       "StringEquals": { "aws:RequestedRegion": [ "us-east-1", "eu-west-1" ] },
       "ForAllValues:StringEquals": { "aws:ResourceTag/NetworkOwner": "net-ops" }
     }
    }
  • Block everyone else attach an SCP that denies directconnect:* unless the principal ARN matches the network-admin roles or the AWS SSO group you designate.
  • Require MFA for sensitive calls add an IAM condition BoolIfExists/aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent : true so console users must present MFA when modifying connections or virtual interfaces.
  • Monitor and audit stream CloudTrail events that match directconnect:* to CloudWatch Logs and set an EventBridge rule to alert on any caller outside your allow-list.
  • Review quarterly export IAM Access Analyzer last used data and remove unused Direct Connect permissions; update Region and tag conditions as your footprint changes.

Enforcing identity-based, least-privilege policies prevents unauthorized creation, deletion, or tampering of Direct Connect links that could disrupt hybrid connectivity.

References

  • What is AWS Direct Connect?

countermeasure.name: Implement BGP hijacking protections
countermeasure.desc:
Protect Direct Connect virtual interfaces from BGP hijacking and route leaks by configuring both ends of the peering sessionyour on-prem router and AWSto accept only authenticated, pre-agreed prefixes and AS paths:

  1. enable BGP MD5 authentication
    • When you create or update the private or transit virtual interface, specify a BGP MD5 key (Amazon console Add BGP password).
    • Configure the matching password <secret> on your customer router so unauthenticated sessions are rejected.
  2. advertise and accept explicit prefix lists
    • On your router, use a prefix-list / route-map that only advertises the exact CIDR blocks you own (no more-specifics, no 0.0.0.0/0).
    • Apply an inbound filter that accepts only the AWS-announced RFC 1918 ranges (or any public space you expect) to prevent a poisoned route table.
  3. set max-prefix & as-path filters
    • neighbor <aws-peering-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5pick N slightly above the number of prefixes you legitimately expect (e.g., 5 % head-room).
    • Deny inbound prefixes whose AS_PATH is not exactly AS16509 (AWS) or the sequence you anticipate for a hosted connection.
  4. enable BFD and low hold timers
    • Turn on Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD) and set aggressive timers (e.g., 300 ms, 3 multiplier) so hijacked or flapping sessions drop quickly.
    • If your device lacks BFD, reduce BGP keep-alive/hold timers (30 / 90 s) instead of the defaults.
  5. monitor and alert
    • Stream Direct Connect BGP state change and RouteChange CloudWatch metrics; alarm on BGPPeerDown, MaxPrefixesExceeded, or unexpected ASN/path events.
    • Log all BGP syslog messages on the customer router to a SIEM and detect new or more-specific routes instantly.
  6. review quarterly
    • Compare advertised prefixes against your IPAM source of truth; prune any stale routes.
    • Rotate the BGP MD5 key when staff leave or devices are replaced.

These layered controlsauthentication, strict prefix/as-path filtering, and rapid failure detectiongreatly reduce the chance that an attacker can hijack your Direct Connect traffic or inject malicious routes.

References

  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities

countermeasure.name: Monitor and safeguard BGP routes
countermeasure.desc:
Continuously watch every Direct Connect BGP session and automatically flagor shut downany route change that could steer traffic to an unexpected destination.

  1. Stream BGP telemetry to CloudWatch
    • Enable the Direct Connect metrics BgpPeerState, BgpRouteFlapDampening, and BGPMaxPrefixesExceeded.
    • Create CloudWatch alarms that fire when a peer drops (BgpPeerState = 3), the route count jumps beyond the configured max-prefix value, or flapping exceeds a defined threshold.
  2. Log all route advertisements
    • On the customer router, export BGP UPDATE messages to a syslog or NetFlow collector; forward to your SIEM for real-time correlation.
    • Retain logs for at least 90 days so you can trace when and how a suspicious prefix entered the table.
  3. Detect drift with AWS Config & EventBridge
    • Deploy a custom AWS Config rule that compares the live list of accepted/advertised prefixes against your approved prefix list in IPAM.
    • When Config marks a resource NON_COMPLIANT, trigger an EventBridge rule that pages on-call staff andoptionallyruns an SSM Automation document to disable the virtual interface until reviewed.
  4. Implement route sanity checks
    • Use the routers prefix-list + route-map to drop any prefix longer than /24 or outside your owned CIDR blocks.
    • Set neighbor <peer-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5 to halt a session that suddenly advertises too many routes.
  5. Visualise and review
    • Build a CloudWatch dashboard that shows current prefix count, peer state, and alarm status for every virtual interface.
    • Review logs and metrics weekly; investigate any new ASN in the AS-PATH or unexplained rise in prefix count.

Proactive monitoring combined with automatic drift detection stops hijacked, leaked, or mis-typed routes before they impact production traffic.

References

  • Monitoring Direct Connect BGP sessions with CloudWatch metrics
  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities

countermeasure.name: Regularly audit Direct Connect configurations
countermeasure.desc:
At least once per quarterand after every network changegenerate and review a complete inventory of Direct Connect resources (connections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associations, route filters, and BGP settings). Compare the live state against your infrastructure-as-code definitions and security baseline, then remediate drift immediately.

Implementation guidance

  1. Automate the snapshot
    • Run aws directconnect describe-* commands (or Terraform / CloudFormation drift-detect) from a scheduled pipeline; export JSON to an S3 bucket versioned for audit.
  2. Evaluate with AWS Config & Security Hub
    • Enable custom and managed Config rulesfor example, flag connections without BGP MD5 keys or VIFs without route filters. Send findings to Security Hub so they appear on your compliance dashboard.
  3. Cross-check critical attributes
    • Verify port speed, LOA expiry, VLAN IDs, SiteLink status, BGP ASN, maximum-prefix limits, and MD5 keys against your approved standards document or IPAM system.
  4. Document and remediate
    • Publish an audit report listing compliant items, drift, and required fixes. Track remediation tasks in your ticket system and confirm closure before the next audit cycle.

Regular, tool-driven audits prevent silent mis-configurations that could break redundancy, expose routes, or violate compliance requirements.

References

  • Evaluating Resources with AWS Config Rules

countermeasure.name: Use PFS-supported cipher suites
countermeasure.desc:
Whether youre calling the AWS APIs that manage Direct Connect or encrypting application payloads that traverse the circuit (for example, TLS to private NLBs or HTTPS to AWS service endpoints), configure the TLS stack so it negotiates only cipher suites that provide Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS)that is, suites that use an ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key exchange such as ECDHE or DHE.

Implementation guidance

  1. restrict the client cipher list
    • On routers, firewalls, and application servers that initiate TLS sessions over Direct Connect, remove all static-key suites (RSA key exchange) and legacy ciphers (3DES, RC4).
    • Keep the list to modern suites such as TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256, TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384, or (preferably) TLS 1.3 defaults.
  2. enforce on inbound endpoints
    • For load balancers and APIs hosted in AWS, select an ELB security policy that requires TLS 1.2/1.3 with PFS (for example ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06).
    • Reject client hellos that offer only non-PFS suites.
  3. verify with automated scans
    • Use openssl s_client -cipher 'aNULL' -connect host:443 and expect no handshake.
    • Schedule weekly or monthly scans (SSLLabs, AWS Inspector network assessments) to confirm no regressions.
  4. monitor for legacy fall-back
    • Enable CloudTrail data-events for ELB and look for TLSNegotiationError.
    • Set CloudWatch alarms on a spike in cipher-mismatch metricsan early sign that a client or server reverted to weak crypto.

PFS ensures that, even if a long-term private key is later compromised, past TLS sessions cannot be decryptedan essential property for protecting high-value traffic flowing over dedicated circuits like AWS Direct Connect.

References

  • Create an HTTPS listener for your Application Load Balancer

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data interception
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data interception involves unauthorized parties gaining access to data as it is being transmitted over the network. This threat compromises the confidentiality and integrity of data sent via AWS Direct Connect, potentially leading to data breaches and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and state-sponsored actors. Attack vectors include man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, compromised network devices, and physical tapping of communication lines.

Impacts

Data interception can result in confidentiality breaches, data integrity compromise, operational disruption, reputational damage, and financial loss.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker intercepts communication between an on-premises network and AWS by positioning themselves between the endpoints, allowing them to eavesdrop or inject malicious data into the communication stream.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access refers to individuals gaining access to AWS Direct Connect resources without proper authorization. This can occur due to weak access controls, compromised credentials, or configuration errors, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized manipulation of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and attackers exploiting compromised credentials. Attack vectors include stolen or weak passwords, misconfigured IAM policies, and exploitation of insufficiently restricted network access.

Impacts

Unauthorized access can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized changes to configurations, financial loss, and reputational damage. It compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the AWS environment.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker gains access to AWS Direct Connect resources by exploiting weak or stolen credentials, allowing them to view or manipulate sensitive data. Another scenario involves a misconfigured IAM policy that inadvertently grants excessive permissions to a user, leading to unauthorized actions within the AWS environment.

threat.name: Insecure configuration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure configuration involves improper setup of AWS Direct Connect resources, leading to potential vulnerabilities. Misconfigurations can result from errors in security settings, inadequate access controls, or failure to follow best practices, exposing the infrastructure to various threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include system administrators, attackers exploiting configuration errors, and automated tools scanning for vulnerabilities. Attack vectors include misconfigured access controls, incorrect security group settings, and failure to apply updates or patches.

Impacts

Insecure configurations can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exploitation of vulnerable systems. These issues can compromise the security and integrity of data and services.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator mistakenly configures overly permissive access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access sensitive data through AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves outdated security settings that an attacker exploits to gain unauthorized access, leading to data breaches and service disruptions.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: BGP hijacking
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

BGP hijacking involves malicious actors rerouting internet traffic by corrupting the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) routing tables. This allows attackers to intercept, monitor, or manipulate data intended for legitimate network paths, potentially impacting AWS Direct Connect's communication routes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, state-sponsored actors, and rogue network operators. Attack vectors involve manipulating BGP announcements to falsely advertise ownership of IP prefixes, causing traffic to be misrouted through the attackers network.

Impacts

BGP hijacking can lead to data interception, traffic analysis, disruption of services, loss of data integrity, and potential data breaches. It can cause significant operational disruptions and loss of trust in network security.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker corrupts BGP routing tables to divert traffic from a corporate network to their own servers, allowing them to capture sensitive information transmitted via AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves an attacker using a compromised or rogue router to announce false BGP routes, disrupting service availability and causing a loss of connectivity for critical applications.

component.name: AWS Lambda
component.desc: AWS Lambda for analytics datasets and query tools.

weakness.name: CWE-1047
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1047: Modules with Circular Dependencies The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

weakness.name: CWE-1193
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1193: Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-312
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-312: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-384
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-384: Session Fixation Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

weakness.name: CWE-416
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-416: Use After Free Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash, use unexpected values, or execute code.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-672
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-672: Operation on a Resource after Expiration or Release The product uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.

weakness.name: CWE-913
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-913: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables, objects, classes, attributes, functions, or executable instructions or statements. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to dynamically create or modify existing code, or resources used by code such as variables and objects. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can directly influence these code resources in unexpected ways.

countermeasure.name: Apply permission boundaries to cap Lambda role and user privileges
countermeasure.desc:
Define a single IAM permission-boundary policy that represents the maximum set of actions a Lambda workload should ever performtypically the core lambda:*, CloudWatch Logs calls, and tightly scoped access to specific AWS resources. Attach that boundary to:

  • Every Lambda execution role (via the PermissionBoundary property in CloudFormation/Terraform).
  • All human or CI/CD principals that can create or update functions.

Because AWS evaluates the boundary before attached or inline policies, anything not explicitly allowed by the boundary is automatically deniedeven if someone tries to grant broader rights later.

quick implementation

  1. Author and publish the boundary
    1. {
       "Version":"2012-10-17",
       "Statement":[
         { "Effect":"Allow", "Action":[
             "lambda:*",
             "logs:CreateLogGroup", "logs:CreateLogStream", "logs:PutLogEvents"
           ], "Resource":"*" },
         { "Effect":"Deny", "Action":[ "iam:*", "organizations:*", "lambda:DeleteFunction" ], "Resource":"*" }
       ]
      }
       
    2. aws iam create-policy --policy-name lambda-boundary --policy-document file://boundary.json
  2. Attach the boundary
    1. aws iam put-role-permissions-boundary \
          --role-name OrderProcessorRole \
          --permissions-boundary arn:aws:iam::<acct>:policy/lambda-boundary
  3. Enforce automatically
    • Add a pipeline check (e.g., cfn-lint, Checkov) that fails if a new role lacks PermissionBoundary.
    • Enable AWS Config rule iam-user-permissions-boundary-check and create a similar custom rule for roles to detect drift.
  4. Maintain
    Review the boundary every quarter: remove unused Allow actions, add new ones only after peer approval, and keep the policy version history in source control.

References

  • Permissions boundaries for IAM entities
  • Lambda security best practices IAM boundaries

countermeasure.name: Deploy VPC Lambda functions across multiple Availability Zones
countermeasure.desc:
For every Lambda function that runs inside a VPC, attach at least two private subnets that reside in different Availability Zones (AZs). Lambda automatically spreads function instances across all subnets you specify, so providing subnets in multiple AZs gives the function resiliency against an AZ-level failure.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet planning In the target VPC, create two or more /24 (or smaller) private subnets, each located in a distinct AZ (for example, subnet-az1a-private, subnet-az1b-private). If the function needs outbound internet access, give every AZ its own NAT gateway or egress path.
  2. Configure the function
    • Console: Configuration VPC Edit select the VPC and tick both (or all) private subnets.
    • AWS CLI / IaC:
      • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
         --function-name order-processor \
         --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0a12,subnet-0b34,SecurityGroupIds=sg-0abc
  3. Security groups Attach a least-privilege security group that allows only the ports and CIDRs the function truly needs (for example, TCP 5432 to an RDS cluster SG).
  4. Guardrails Implement an AWS Config custom rule or cfn-nag check that fails a deployment when a VPC-connected Lambda lists fewer than two subnets.
  5. Validation & monitoring Use the Lambda consoles Monitoring Subnet metrics or CloudWatchs Duration metrics to confirm invocations appear from each AZ. Include a canary test that fires if an AZs invocations drop to zero.

Spreading subnets across Availability Zones ensures the function continues to invoke even if one AZor its networking componentsbecomes unavailable.

References

  • AWS Lambda resilience guidance
  • Create more than one subnet across different AZ

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Lambda env vars and code artifacts with customer-managed KMS keys
countermeasure.desc:
Safeguard every sensitive value that AWS Lambda storesenvironment variables, .zip deployment packages, container images, and event-filter criteriaby encrypting them with an AWS KMS customer-managed key (CMK) instead of the default AWS-managed key. Using your own CMK lets you control key rotation, scope decrypt permissions tightly, and audit every use.

1 . Create or choose a CMK

aws kms create-key --description "Lambda data-at-rest CMK"
aws kms enable-key-rotation --key-id <key-id>

Limit the key policy to the Lambda service principal and the minimal set of roles that need kms:Decrypt / kms:GenerateDataKey.

2 . Encrypt environment variables

  • Console / IaC: set the KMS key ARN field (CloudFormation KmsKeyArn, Terraform kms_key_arn).
  • CLI:
    • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
          --function-name order-processor \
          --kms-key-arn arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd

Lambda now uses your CMK to encrypt Env Vars and event-filter JSON.

3 . Protect deployment artifacts

  • .zip packages in S3 store them in a bucket with SSE-KMS and the same CMK:
    • aws s3api put-bucket-encryption \
          --bucket lambda-artifacts-prod \
          --server-side-encryption-configuration \
          '{"Rules":[{"ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault":
             {"SSEAlgorithm":"aws:kms","KMSMasterKeyID":"alias/lambda-data"}}]}'
  • Container images in ECR ensure the ECR repository uses KMS encryption with your CMK.

4 . Grant least-privilege KMS access

Add this statement (scoped to the CMK ARN) to the functions execution role:

{
 "Effect": "Allow",
 "Action": [
   "kms:Decrypt",
   "kms:GenerateDataKey*"
 ],
 "Resource": "arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd"
}

5 . Continuous assurance

  • Enable AWS Config rule lambda-function-env-vars-encrypted (or a custom rule) to flag functions without a CMK.
  • Create CloudWatch alarms on KMS metric NumberOfFailedDecryptRequests.
  • Rotate the CMK annually; update KmsKeyArn in templates, then disable the old key after confirming no decrypt errors.

Encrypting Lambda data with your own KMS keys gives you full custody of cryptographic material, meets stringent compliance mandates, and lets you trace every decrypt back to an invoking principal.

References

  • Encrypting environment variables and artifacts with a customer-managed KMS key
  • Using AWS KMS keys with AWS Lambda

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Enforce bootstrap-aware CI/CD reviews and linting
countermeasure.desc:
To implement the security countermeasure that safeguards AWS Lambda custom runtimes by treating 'bootstrap' and Lambda runtime layers as sensitive code, follow the steps outlined below:

  1. Establish a Peer Review Process:
    • Define a policy that mandates peer reviews for any changes to files named 'bootstrap' or runtime layers containing 'bootstrap'.
    • Implement a system in your version control platform (e.g., GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket) that explicitly requires an "approval" label before merging code involving these sensitive components.
    • Ensure that reviewers are experienced in security practices and familiar with Lambda runtimes.
  2. Deploy Static Code Analysis Tools:
    • Integrate static analysis tools (e.g., Checkmarx, SonarQube) into the CI/CD pipeline.
    • Configure these tools to flag and fail builds when detected risky constructs such as:
      • curl, wget, or nc
      • Any usage of bash -c
      • Unchecked or blind network egress calls
    • Introduce an allowlist mechanism where risky constructs can only bypass checks if accompanied by a written, justified reason reviewed and approved by security teams.
  3. Restrict Bootstrap Role:
    • Verify that the 'bootstrap' file solely performs runtime initialization tasks and invokes the handler or Runtime Interface Client (RIC) as designed.
    • Apply rules to forbid any embedded persistence, telemetry beacons, or additional functionality within the 'bootstrap', unless explicitly approved through the peer-review process.
    • Audit the 'bootstrap' code periodically to ensure compliance with these restrictions.
  4. Enforce Pipeline-Only Deployment:
    • Block any direct uploads of Lambda runtime layers or the 'bootstrap' file via the AWS Management Console.
    • Configure permissions so that developers can only deploy changes through a CI/CD pipeline that enforces defined security checks.
    • Apply IAM policies to prevent unauthorized access to runtime layer modification workflows.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda Official Documentation
  • AWS CodePipeline Documentation
  • AWS Security Blog

countermeasure.name: Enforce code-signed Lambda deployments with AWS Signer
countermeasure.desc:
Guarantee that only vetted code reaches production by pairing AWS Signer with a Lambda Code Signing Configuration (CSC): every deployment package must be signed with your approved signing profile before Lambda accepts it.

  1. Create a signing profile
    1. aws signer put-signing-profile \
       --profile-name prod-lambda-code \
       --platform-id AWSLambda-SHA384-ECDSA
  2. Store the profile ARN in your CI/CD secrets.
  3. Integrate signing into the pipeline
    • Package the ZIP or container image, then call aws signer start-signing-job (ZIP) or ECR image signing (container).
    • Fail the build if the signing job status isnt Succeeded.
  4. Define a Code Signing Configuration
    1. aws lambda create-code-signing-config \
       --allowed-publishers SigningProfileVersionArns=arn:aws:signer::profile/prod-lambda-code/* \
       --code-signing-policies UntrustedArtifactOnDeployment=Enforce
  5. Enforce blocks any unsigned or differently-signed artifact.
  6. Attach the CSC to functions
    1. aws lambda update-function-code-signing-config \
       --function-name orders-handler \
       --code-signing-config-arn arn:aws:lambda::code-signing-config:csc-abc123
  7. Include this step in all CloudFormation/Terraform modules so drift is impossible.
  8. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Enable the AWS Config rule lambda-function-code-signing-config-enabled to detect functions without a CSC.
    • Use EventBridge to alert when a deployment fails due to CodeSigningError, signalling a bypass attempt or pipeline mis-sign.
  9. Key hygiene
    • Rotate the Signer KMS key annually; update the signing profile to the new key version.
    • Restrict signer:StartSigningJob permission to the build role; deny it in production accounts via SCPs.

By requiring AWS-signed packages and enforcing CSCs, you shut the door on tampered artifacts, typo-squatted libraries, and shadow deployments.

References

  • Code signing for AWS Lambda
  • AWS Signer Developer Guide

countermeasure.name: Enforce tagging standards on Lambda functions
countermeasure.desc:
Every Lambda function must carry a complete, standardized tag set for example Environment, Owner, CostCenter, and Compliance so that security, cost-allocation, and automation workflows can rely on consistent metadata.

How to implement

  1. Define the mandatory keys in a central document (e.g., tagging-standard.md) and publish it to your IaC repository.
  2. Validate in the pipeline
    • Add a build step (cfn-lint/Checkov/GitHub Action, etc.) that fails if the template or aws lambda create-function command omits any required tag.
  3. Enforce at runtime with AWS Config
    • Enable the managed rule required-tags or deploy a custom rule that checks the AWS::Lambda::Function resource type and your mandatory tag list.
    • Configure the rule for continuous evaluation and send non-compliant findings to Security Hub or an SNS topic that opens a ticket.
  4. Auto-remediate or quarantine
    • Attach an EventBridge rule to run an SSM Automation or Lambda fixer script that adds missing tagsor, in strict environments, disables the function until tags are corrected.
  5. Review quarterly
    • Spot-check tag accuracy (e.g., does the Owner tag still map to an active identity?) and update the standard when new reporting requirements appear.

Automated tagging enforcement guarantees that every Lambda function can be located, costed, and governed, while eliminating drift caused by manual provisioning.

References

  • Tagging Lambda functions
  • AWS Config rule required-tags

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2+ with perfect-forward-secrecy for all Lambda traffic
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure every network path that carries AWS Lambda control-plane or data-plane trafficCLI / SDK calls to the Lambda API, Function URLs, ALB/API Gateway invokes, VPC egress, and third-party integrationsnegotiates TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3 using PFS cipher suites (ECDHE or DHE). Disable legacy SSL/TLS versions and static-key ciphers to eliminate downgrade and session-key compromise risks.

Implementation guidance

  1. Runtime & library hardening
    • Use current AWS SDKs, AWS CLI v2, and OS packages (OpenSSL 1.1.1, Java 8 u181, .NET 4.6) that default to TLS 1.2+.
    • In container images or AMIs set MinProtocol = TLSv1.2 and remove *_RSA_* suites from the cipher list.
  2. Outbound Lambda networking
    • When the function runs in a VPC, allow only TCP 443 to interface endpoints (S3, STS, Secrets Manager, etc.). Block port 80 in security groups and route tables.
    • For external calls, pin the destination to https:// URIs and verify certificates (e.g., with Python requests.verify=True).
  3. Inbound invoke paths
    • Function URLs: set AuthType=AWS_IAM or another auth method; TLS is auto-enforced by AWS but add a WAF rule that blocks any request with the X-Forwarded-Proto != https.
    • API Gateway / ALB: enable TLS 1.2 minimum on the custom domain or listener policy; prefer ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06.
    • For IoT or custom MQTT, use certificates that advertise only TLS 1.2/1.3 and EC cipher suites.
  4. Central guardrails
    • Attach an SCP that denies lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl or execute-api:Invoke when aws:SecureTransport is false.
    • Deploy AWS Config rules or cfn-nag checks that fail if an ALB listener policy includes TLS 1.0/1.1 or if a VPC security group permits port 80 egress.
  5. Continuous verification
    • Add a CI test that attempts openssl s_client -connect lambda.<region>.amazonaws.com:443 -tls1_1 and expect failure; succeed with -tls1_2.
    • Scan AMIs and containers monthly with Inspector or OpenSCAP for outdated OpenSSL/LibreSSL versions.
  6. Incident response & patching
    • Subscribe to AWS Security Bulletins; redeploy all Lambda runtime layers when critical TLS CVEs are announced.
    • Rotate any function URL or API Gateway custom certificates that use deprecated algorithms (RSA-1024, SHA-1).

Following this control guarantees strong, modern encryption end-to-end, satisfying compliance frameworks and protecting Lambda workloads against passive interception and forward-decryption attacks.

References

  • TLS 1.2 to become the minimum for all AWS service endpoints
  • Best practices for AWS Lambda security

countermeasure.name: Grant least-privilege IAM permissions to Lambda execution roles
countermeasure.desc:
Create a dedicated IAM role for every Lambda function and attach only the permissions the code truly needsnothing more, nothing wildcard.

  1. Inventory required actions
    • List each AWS API the function calls (e.g., dynamodb:PutItem, s3:GetObject, secretsmanager:GetSecretValue).
    • Add logs:CreateLogGroup, logs:CreateLogStream, and logs:PutLogEvents for basic logging if they arent provided by a shared policy.
  2. Author a scoped policy
    • Restrict Resource to exact ARNs (specific table, bucket prefix, secret) instead of *.
    • Where possible, add condition keysfor example dynamodb:LeadingKeys, s3:prefix, aws:SourceVpc, or tagbased conditions.
  3. Attach the policy to a unique execution role
    • Console: Configuration Permissions choose or create role.
    • IaC example (CloudFormation):
      • LambdaRole:
         Type: AWS::IAM::Role
         Properties:
           AssumeRolePolicyDocument:
             Statement:
               - Effect: Allow
                 Principal: Service: lambda.amazonaws.com
                 Action: sts:AssumeRole
           Policies:
             - PolicyName: OrdersFunctionPolicy
               PolicyDocument: {...}   # actions/resources from step 2
  4. Remove default privileges
    • Delete unused AWS-managed policies like AWSLambdaFullAccess.
    • Never attach AdministratorAccess or * actionsfail the pipeline if these appear.
  5. Continuous validation
    • Enable IAM Access Analyzer unused permissions and prune actions that havent been called for 90 days.
    • Deploy AWS Config rule iam-managed-policy-check or a cfn-nag/Checkov rule in CI to block wildcard actions or resources.
  6. Review regularly
    • Re-run Access Analyzer after each feature release.
    • Rotate any secrets or keys the function accesses, updating the role policy as needed.

Applying strict, role-specific policies limits blast radius, supports the principle of least privilege, and satisfies compliance auditors looking for excessive permissions.

References

  • Security best practices for AWS Lambda
  • IAM Access Analyzer

countermeasure.name: Isolate Lambda network traffic with locked-down VPC subnets and security groups
countermeasure.desc:
Run every Lambda function inside a dedicated set of private subnets and attach it to a least-privilege security group so the function can reach only the services it truly needsnothing else.

How to implement

  1. Create lambda-only private subnets
    • Place them in the application VPC but do not route them to an Internet Gateway.
    • If outbound internet access is required, send traffic through a shared NAT Gateway or a VPC endpoint (for S3, DynamoDB, etc.).
  2. Define a restrictive security group
    • Egress rules: allow only the ports and CIDRs (or other SGs) that correspond to your dependenciesfor example, TCP 5432 to an RDS SG, HTTPS (443) to a Secrets Manager VPC endpoint SG. Remove the default all traffic egress rule.
    • Ingress rules: normally none are required; Lambda creates connections out of the subnet. If the function must be called by an internal ALB, allow only that ALBs SG on the listener port.
  3. Attach the VPC config to the function
    1. aws lambda update-function-configuration \
       --function-name payment-handler \
       --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0aa123,subnet-0bb456 \
                   SecurityGroupIds=sg-0lambda
  4. Guardrails and drift detection
    • Add an AWS Config rule (or cfn-nag/Checkov policy) that fails if a Lambda SG allows 0.0.0.0/0 or if the subnet route table points to an Internet Gateway.
    • Monitor VPC Flow Logs for unexpected destinations; tighten SG rules when new patterns appear.
  5. Document and review
    • Keep subnet IDs and SG IDs in your IaC modules so every environment uses the same isolation model.
    • Re-evaluate access rules quarterly or whenever the functions dependencies change.

Locking Lambda functions into isolated subnets and SGs minimizes lateral movement, reduces the attack surface, and satisfies segmentation requirements without sacrificing performance.

References

  • Configuring a Lambda function to access VPC resources
  • AWS Lambda security best practices network isolation

countermeasure.name: Keep Lambda functions on supported runtimes
countermeasure.desc:
AWS periodically deprecates Lambda runtimes (Node .js, Python, Java, .NET, Ruby, Go). A function that keeps running on an out-of-support runtime no longer receives security patches, and AWS may block deployments after the end-of-life date.

Implementation guidance

  1. Baseline now list every function and its runtime:
    1. aws lambda list-functions --query 'Functions[*].[FunctionName,Runtime]' --output table

Flag anything marked deprecated in the [runtime support policy].

  1. Automate continuous checks
    • Enable the managed AWS Config rule lambda-function-running-supported-runtime (or a custom rule) so any function on an outdated runtime is immediately marked NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Forward Config notifications to an SNS topic tied to your ticketing system or ChatOps channel.
  2. Update promptly
    • Track AWS deprecation announcements; add the EOL date to your backlog.
    • Use feature branches to bump the runtime version in your IaC (SAM/CloudFormation/Terraform) and CI pipeline, run tests, then deploy.
    • For container images, rebuild from an up-to-date base image and push a new tag.
  3. Prevent drift
    • Add a pipeline gate that rejects any create-function or update-function-configuration call if the --runtime flag is not in your approved list.
    • For containers, scan the image in CodeBuild/CodePipeline with AWS Inspector or Trivy before deployment.
  4. Review quarterly
    Re-run the baseline script or a Config compliance report; remove any temporary suppression and schedule upgrades for newly announced EOL runtimes.

Keeping all functions on supported runtimes guarantees ongoing security patches, performance optimisations, and access to the latest Lambda features.

References

  • AWS Lambda runtimes supported versions and deprecation policy
  • AWS Config rule lambda-function-running-supported-runtime
