countermeasure.name: Log all Lambda API activity with CloudTrail and secure S3 storage
countermeasure.desc:
Create an organization-wide, multi-Region CloudTrail trail that records every AWS Lambda management eventfunction creation, configuration updates, permission changes, InvokeFunction calls, and Function URL operationsand delivers the logs to a hardened S3 bucket for long-term retention and forensic search.

Implementation steps

  1. Enable a multi-Region trail
    • Console: CloudTrail Trails Create trail select Apply trail to all Regions and log Management events Read + Write (Lambda is covered automatically).
    • CLI / IaC example:
      • aws cloudtrail create-trail \
         --name org-lambda-trail \
         --s3-bucket-name org-trail-logs \
         --is-multi-region-trail
        aws cloudtrail start-logging --name org-lambda-trail
  2. Protect the S3 log bucket
    • Block public access and require TLS in the bucket policy:
      • "Condition": { "Bool": { "aws:SecureTransport": "false" } }
    • Enable SSE-KMS encryption with a customer-managed key; limit key-policy access to the CloudTrail service principal and your security team.
    • Turn on log file validation and bucket versioning to detect tampering.
  3. Retention & analytics
    • Apply lifecycle rules: e.g., keep logs in the S3 Standard tier for 90 days, then transition to Glacier Instant Retrieval or Deep Archive, deleting after seven years.
    • Optionally send the trail to CloudWatch Logs or Lake Formation for near-real-time detection and SQL-based hunting.
  4. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Deploy AWS Config rules such as cloudtrail-enabled and s3-bucket-server-side-encryption-enabled so any drift triggers alerts.
    • Create EventBridge rules that notify your on-call channel when someone issues StopLogging, DeleteTrail, or changes the bucket policy.
  5. Periodic review
    • Quarterly, confirm that new AWS Regions and new Lambda features are still captured, and rotate or disable unused KMS keys and IAM principals.
    • Validate integrity with aws cloudtrail validate-logs during tabletop or incident-response exercises.

Implementing centralized, secure CloudTrail logging for Lambda provides an immutable audit trail that supports compliance, incident response, and continuous improvement of your serverless security posture.

References

  • Logging AWS Lambda API calls with AWS CloudTrail
  • Best practices for CloudTrail log file integrity and S3 security

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

countermeasure.name: Monitor package hash and bootstrap integrity
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing robust security countermeasures for AWS Lambda custom runtimes involves the following steps:

  1. Record Approved CodeSha256:
    • For every deployment of AWS Lambda, compute the CodeSha256 hash of the deployed function package using the AWS CLI or SDK.
    • Maintain an allowlist of approved CodeSha256 hashes in a secure system, such as AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store or a Configuration Management Database (CMDB) with audit logs enabled for modifications.
  2. Monitor Drift through EventBridge:
    • Create an EventBridge rule to capture UpdateFunctionCode events from CloudTrail. Configure CloudTrail to log all function updates to ensure full visibility of unplanned changes.
    • When an UpdateFunctionCode event is triggered, invoke a Lambda function or automation workflow that runs get-function against the affected Lambda function.
    • Compare the reported CodeSha256 from get-function output against the stored allowlist of approved hashes.
    • If a discrepancy is identified, create a high-severity finding and alert relevant teams immediately using an integrated mechanism such as AWS Security Hub or Amazon SNS.
  3. Verify Integrity During CI/CD:
    • In your CI/CD pipeline, compute and store a checksum for the bootstrap file (or its layer path) during the packaging step of Lambda custom runtimes.
    • For container-based runtimes, capture the digests of the container image and validate the ENTRYPOINT and CMD against the approved baselines stored during CI.
    • Post-deploy, verify the deployed checksums match the precomputed checksums from the CI/CD pipeline.
  4. Persist Integrity Metadata:
    • Store integrity metadata such as approved hashes, container digests, and runtime file checksums in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store, with secure access controls to limit modifications to authorized personnel or automation scripts.
    • Enable versioning and tagging for stored metadata to support audit trails and provide recovery options in case of accidental modifications.
  5. Detect Unauthorized Bootstrap Changes:
    • Ensure that bootstrap file integrity validation is part of runtime monitoring. Regularly automate hash comparisons and include mechanisms for detecting tampering during runtime or in transit.
    • Integrate findings from the above monitoring mechanisms into AWS Security Hub or a centralized incident management tool for triage and resolution.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda CodeSha256
  • Using CloudTrail with Amazon EventBridge
  • AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store
  • AWS Security Hub

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Require AWS_IAM authentication on Lambda function URLs
countermeasure.desc:
When you expose an AWS Lambda function through a Function URL, set the AuthType to AWS_IAM so that every invoke request must be SigV4-signed by an IAM principal with an explicit allow on lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl. This prevents unauthenticated internet traffic from reaching the function and lets you apply fine-grained least-privilege policies, MFA enforcement, and session-duration limits.

Implementation steps

  1. Create or update the Function URL
    1. aws lambda create-function-url-config \
         --function-name orders-handler \
         --auth-type AWS_IAM \
         --cors AllowedOrigins=https://app.example.com
      #or
      aws lambda update-function-url-config \
         --function-name orders-handler \
         --auth-type AWS_IAM
  2. Authorize callers
    • Add an IAM policy that allows lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl on the function ARN with /url suffix:
      arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:123456789012:function:orders-handler:url
    • Scope the policy to trusted roles or users; require MFA or session tags if needed.
  3. Invoke securely
    • Clients must include an Authorization header with a SigV4 signature (aws4_request).
    • For browsers, front the URL with API Gateway or CloudFront signed cookies if you cant sign requests client-side.
  4. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Deploy an AWS Config rule or SCP that prevents AuthType: NONE in production accounts.
    • Stream Lambda access logs to CloudWatch; alert on 403 errors to detect unauthorized attempts.

Using AWS_IAM authentication ensures only vetted principals can reach the function, leveraging the full power of IAM policies and audit trails.

References

  • Using IAM authorization for Lambda function URLs
  • lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl permissions and examples

standard.ref: AC-14 PERMITTED ACTIONS WITHOUT IDENTIFICATION OR AUTHENTICATION
AC-19 Access Control for Mobile Devices

countermeasure.name: Require MFA for root and IAM users
countermeasure.desc:
Protect the AWS account against credential theft by enforcing multi-factor authentication (MFA) on the root user and every IAM user:

  1. Enable MFA devices
    • Root user: sign in as root and register a hardware key, FIDO2 passkey, or virtual TOTP device at Account Security credentials Multi-factor authentication.
    • IAM users: in the IAM console or CLI (aws iam enable-mfa-device), attach a virtual or hardware MFA device to each user. Automate user creation so MFA is required before console access is granted.
  2. Block sessions without MFA
    • Attach an IAM policy that denies all actions when aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent is false.
    • Apply an SCP at the OU or root level that prevents non-MFA console logins in production accounts.
  3. Monitor and enforce
    • Turn on AWS Config managed rules root-account-mfa-enabled and iam-user-mfa-enabled; alert when they report NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Stream CloudTrail to Security Hub and create findings if DeactivateMFADevice, DeleteVirtualMFADevice, or root logins without MFA occur.
  4. Operational hygiene
    • Register two MFA devices for the root user (primary and backup).
    • Review the IAM credential report monthly; disable or delete any user lacking MFA or with unused access keys.

Implementing mandatory MFA shuts down most credential-stuffing, phishing, and console-token replay attacks, forming the first and strongest line of defense for all Lambda-related and broader AWS operations.

References

  • Enable MFA for the root user
  • Using MFA with IAM users

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Restrict lambda resource-based policies to explicit principals
countermeasure.desc:
Whenever you add a resource-based policy to a Lambda function (e.g., when granting another AWS account, an AWS service, or an API Gateway permission to invoke it), list only the exact IAM principal ARNs or service principals that require access.
Do not use wildcard principals ("*"), anonymous principals, or broad AWS service wildcards ("lambda.amazonaws.com" without conditions). Wildcards expose the function to unintended callers and defeat least-privilege design.

implementation checklist

  1. author precise statements
    1. {
       "Effect": "Allow",
       "Principal": { "AWS": "arn:aws:iam::444455556666:role/PaymentService" },
       "Action": "lambda:InvokeFunction",
       "Resource": "arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:111122223333:function:ProcessPayment"
      }
  2. Specify the consuming account ID and role name; for cross-account access, pair with aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount condition keys.
  3. block wildcards in CI/CD
    • Add cfn-nag / Checkov / cfn-guard rules that fail a build if Principal equals "*" or if no Condition keys are present for an AWS service principal.
  4. continuous compliance
    • Enable AWS Config rule lambda-function-public-access-prohibited (or a custom rule) to detect policies with public or wildcard principals and mark them NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Subscribe Security Hub to forward findings to your on-call channel so unintended permissions are fixed immediately.
  5. review quarterly
    • Use IAM Access Analyzer to enumerate current function resource policies and highlight new external principals.
    • Remove any stale or unused permissions.

Adhering to explicit-principal policies limits who can invoke or manage your Lambda functions, sharply reducing the risk of unauthorized access or privilege escalation.

References

  • Controlling access with resource-based policies for Lambda
  • AWS Config managed rule

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1036 - Account Use Policies

countermeasure.name: Restrict UpdateFunctionCode and enforce immutable release flow
countermeasure.desc:
1. Restrict IAM permissions for Lambda updates:
    • Create or update IAM policies to restrict the lambda:UpdateFunctionCode and lambda:PublishVersion actions to a dedicated CI/CD principal.
    • Implement permission boundaries or Service Control Policies (SCPs) to enforce restrictions across accounts. Examples include denying human users access to these actions entirely in production environments.
    • Test the IAM policies with tools such as AWS IAM Access Analyzer to ensure that only the CI principal has access to these sensitive actions.
  2. Enforce code signing during deployment:
    • Enable and configure Lambda Code Signing by creating a code signing configuration (CSC) that includes trusted signing profiles.
    • Update deployment workflows to use the CSC. Add IAM conditions such as lambda:CodeSigningConfigArn to ensure that only signed artifacts can be deployed.
    • Use versions and aliases to promote changes instead of enabling direct edits:
      • Publish a new function version after deployment.
      • Update aliases to point explicitly to the new version.
  3. Disallow edits to the $LATEST version in production:
    • Disable direct updates to the $LATEST function version for production accounts using IAM policies.
    • Implement governance practices that require testing and approval in staging environments before updating versions or aliases in production.
  4. Establish integrity monitoring and alerts:
    • Enable AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config to track events related to Lambda code updates, especially UpdateFunctionCode and PublishVersion.
    • Create Amazon CloudWatch alarms or EventBridge rules for detecting unauthorized edits or direct code updates, both via the AWS Management Console and SDK.
    • Set up automated workflows to quarantine compromised functions:
      • Disable traffic to affected aliases if integrity verification fails.
      • Notify security teams for manual review and approval.
  5. Implement immutable and auditable CI/CD pipelines:
    • Design CI/CD workflows that ensure all artifacts deployed are code-signed and verified.
    • Adopt tools such as AWS CodePipeline or external pipelines like Jenkins, GitHub Actions, etc., to enforce versioning and signing practices.
    • Use version control systems and tags to establish traceable records for every production release.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda Code Signing
  • IAM Permission Boundaries
  • Service Control Policies (SCPs)
  • AWS CodePipeline
  • Amazon CloudWatch
  • AWS CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Use PrivateLink interface endpoints for Lambda and supporting services
countermeasure.desc:
Create interface VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) for AWS Lambda and every service the function relies onLambda control plane (com.amazonaws.<region>.lambda), Function URLs (com.amazonaws.<region>.lambda-url), and supporting endpoints such as S3, ECR API/ECR DKR, CloudWatch Logs, KMS, DynamoDB, SQS, or Kinesisso that all deployment, invoke, and dependency traffic stays on the AWS backbone instead of the public internet.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet selection choose at least two private subnets in different Availability Zones to give Lambda enough ENIs for scaling and AZ-level resilience.
  2. Provision endpoints create each endpoint with the AWS CLI or IaC:
    1. aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint \
         --vpc-id vpc-1234abcd \
         --service-name com.amazonaws.eu-west-1.lambda \
         --vpc-endpoint-type Interface \
         --subnet-ids subnet-a subnet-b \
         --security-group-ids sg-lambda-endpoints
  3. keep Private DNS enabled so the standard service hostname automatically resolves to the VPC-local IPs.
  4. Harden network access attach a security group that allows only TCP 443 from Lambda subnets or CI/CD hosts; block port 80 entirely.
  5. Apply endpoint policies restrict calls to the exact actions your workload needs (e.g., lambda:InvokeFunction, lambda:GetLayerVersion) and, if required, add aws:SourceVpce or aws:SourceVpc conditions for defense-in-depth.
  6. Lock function resource policies when using Function URLs or cross-account invokes, include StringEquals {"aws:SourceVpce":"vpce-"} so internet-sourced requests are rejected even if a public path exists.
  7. Validate from a private instance run dig lambda.<region>.amazonaws.com and confirm it returns a 10.x address; disable the NAT Gateway temporarily and verify that deployments and invokes still succeed.
  8. Monitor and audit enable VPC Flow Logs for the endpoint ENIs, set CloudWatch alarms on rejected flows, and add an AWS Config rule that flags production VPCs missing the Lambda endpoint.

PrivateLink keeps Lambda control-plane and data traffic inside AWS, reduces latency, simplifies firewall rules, and satisfies compliance mandates that prohibit internet egress for sensitive workloads.

References

  • Interface VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) for Lambda
  • AWS PrivateLink basics and best practices

countermeasure.name: Use temporary credentials via AWS STS
countermeasure.desc:
Give every Lambda function, service, CI/CD pipeline, and human operator an IAM role to assume rather than a static IAM user with access-key pairs. When a principal assumes the role, AWS Security Token Service (STS) hands back short-lived credentials (default 1 h) that AWS rotates automatically. This removes permanent secrets from code, cuts the blast radius of a leaked key, and lets you attach granular, least-privilege policies to each role.

Implementation steps

  1. Create purpose-built roles one per Lambda function (execution role) and one per developer or automation persona. Scope policies to the minimum actions and resources needed.
  2. Configure assumption paths
    • AWS services: add the service principal (e.g., lambda.amazonaws.com, codebuild.amazonaws.com) to the roles trust policy so it can call sts:AssumeRole.
    • Humans/federation: use IAM Identity Center, SAML, or OIDC to let users assume their role after MFA.
  3. Remove static keys disable or delete legacy IAM users and hard-coded keys; store only the role ARN in configuration.
  4. Set sensible session limits keep MaxSessionDuration low (15 min1 h for interactive work; 12 h for workloads).
  5. Monitor & audit enable CloudTrail and IAM Access Analyzer to track who assumes which role; alert on unexpected roles or unusually long sessions.

Adopting STS-based roles wipes out long-lived credentials, enforces just-in-time access, and aligns with AWS recommended security posture.

References

  • Temporary credentials with AWS STS
  • Best practices for AWS Lambda IAM roles

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: SingleAZ failure for VPC functions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions are placed in a VPC that spans only a single Availability Zone, an AZ outage (due to hardware failure, networking issues, or scheduled maintenance) renders those functions unable to access their ENIs, subnets, or dependent servicescausing complete service disruption.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • AWS Infrastructure Failures: Power, network, or hardware faults isolated to one AZ.
  • Misconfiguration: VPC subnet or NAT gateway deployment limited to a single AZ.
  • Capacity Events: AZspecific resource exhaustion (e.g., ENI limits reached) preventing new function attachments.

Impacts

  • Service Outage: Affected Lambdas cannot execute, disrupting APIs, event processing, or backend jobs.
  • Data Delays: Queues and streams back up, leading to timesensitive data loss or processing lag.
  • Operational Costs: Emergency redeployments or crossAZ workarounds consume engineering time and may incur extra charges.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. AZ Hardware Failure: A hardware fault knocks out networking in AZA; all Lambda functions in that singleAZ VPC lose ENI attachment and fail to process inbound events.
  2. NAT Gateway Capacity Spike: A DDoS flood targets the NAT gateway in the lone AZ, saturating its throughput; VPCbound Lambdas cant reach the internet for API calls.
  3. Planned AZ Maintenance: AWS schedules maintenance that briefly disables ENI provisioning in AZB; because all subnets reside there, no new Lambda invocations succeed until maintenance completes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Outdated runtime environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Outdated runtime environments occur when Lambda functions continue using deprecated or unpatched language runtimes (e.g. old Node.js, Python, Java versions), missing security fixes and performance improvements.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers scanning for known CVEs, supplychain adversaries embedding exploits in dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting publicly documented vulnerabilities in EOL runtimes.
    • Injecting malicious payloads through outdated library transitive dependencies.
    • Leveraging insecure default configurations tied to legacy runtimes.

Impacts

  • Remote Code Execution: Attackers exploit CVEs to run arbitrary code in your functions.
  • Data Breach: Compromised functions expose sensitive input or environment data.
  • Service Disruption: Unpatched bugs cause function crashes or performance failures.
  • Compliance Risks: Use of unsupported runtimes may violate organizational or regulatory policies.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CVE Exploit: A function running Python2.7 is targeted with a known bufferoverflow exploit, allowing an attacker to execute shell commands.
  2. Dependency Hijack: An outdated Node.js runtime pulls in a vulnerable version of a logging library; an attacker injects malicious code via crafted log messages.
  3. Misconfiguration Crash: A Java8 function uses an old JDBC driver with memoryleak bugs, causing repeated OOM errors and denial of service under load.

threat.name: Overly broad IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly broad IAM permissions occur when AWS Lambda execution roles or associated policies grant more privileges than necessaryoften using wildcards for actions or resourcesexposing your functions to escalate privileges or access unrelated services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised deployment pipelines, and external attackers using stolen credentials.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • IAM policies with "Action": "lambda:*" or "*" on "Resource": "*" attached to function roles.
    • Overpermissive trust relationships allowing any principal to assume the Lambda role.
    • Failure to apply leastprivilege when granting access to AWS services (S3, DynamoDB, IAM).

Impacts

  • Privilege Escalation: Functions can call APIs beyond their scope (e.g., creating or deleting roles).
  • Data Breach: Exfiltration of sensitive data from S3 buckets, databases, or Secrets Manager.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised functions pivot to other services or resources in your account.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended changes to infrastructure, such as spinning up expensive resources or deleting critical stacks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Overreach: A Lambda role with s3:* on * is compromised; the attacker lists and downloads all buckets, harvesting PII.
  2. IAM Role Abuse: An overly broad iam:* permission lets a malicious function create a new admin user, granting full account control.
  3. Cost Shock: A function granted ec2:RunInstances and ec2:TerminateInstances is hijacked to spin up large fleets of instances, incurring massive charges and then deleting them to cover tracks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Credential compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Credential compromise in AWS Lambda occurs when the secrets, API keys, or IAM credentials used by functions are exposed or stoleneither through code, environment variables, or execution contextallowing attackers to impersonate or control your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, automated bots, thirdparty library leaks, compromised CI/CD pipelines
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Embedding secrets (AWS keys, database passwords) in function code or plaintext environment variables
    • Retrieving IAM role tokens from the Lambda execution environment via SSRF or metadataendpoint exploits
    • Exposing credentials in version control systems, build artifacts, or CloudWatch logs

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Function Invocation: Attackers invoke functions at will, potentially incurring costs or executing unwanted actions
  • Privilege Escalation & Lateral Movement: Stolen credentials grant access to other AWS services or higherprivilege roles
  • Data Exfiltration & Tampering: Sensitive data processed by Lambdas (e.g., PII, business logic) can be read or modified
  • Service Disruption & Financial Loss: Illicit use of credentials can flood queues, trigger throttling, or bill for large-scale invocations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hardcoded Key Leak: A developer commits a Lambda function with embedded AWS keys to GitHub. An attacker clones the repo, uses the keys to read S3 buckets, and exfiltrates customer data.
  2. Metadata Endpoint Abuse: A malicious library loaded into the Lambda execution environment makes HTTP calls to the IMDS endpoint, harvesting the functions IAM role token and using it to spin up new EC2 instances.
  3. Log Exposure: A misconfigured logging library prints database credentials from environment variables to CloudWatch Logs; a compromised IAM principal with logs:GetLogEvents reads the logs and uses the credentials to drop the database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550.001 - Application Access Token

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Lack of network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions share flat or overly permissive network configurationssuch as residing in default VPC subnets without segmentation or securitygroup restrictionsthey gain unfettered access to internal systems and the internet, increasing risk of lateral movement and data exfiltration.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Compromised function code, malicious insiders, or thirdparty dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting broad VPC subnet placement to reach databases, caches, or internal APIs.
    • Using SSRF or openredirect flaws within the function to pivot across network boundaries.
    • Leveraging unrestricted egress to exfiltrate data to attackercontrolled endpoints.

Impacts

  • Lateral Movement: Attackers breach internal resources (e.g., RDS, Redis) via the compromised functions network path.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive payloads or environment variables are sent out over the internet.
  • Service Compromise: Unauthorized access to microservices, service meshes, or backend systems, undermining confidentiality and integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Database Pivot: A stolen function token is used to invoke a Lambda in the default VPC, which then connects to an internal MySQL cluster on port3306 to dump data.
  2. Internal Reconnaissance: An attacker injects SSRF payloads into a function endpoint, causing it to scan internal HTTP management interfaces and map out privileged services.
  3. Covert Exfiltration: A compromised dependency causes the function to upload decrypted S3 objects to an attackers external SFTP server, bypassing network ACLs.

threat.name: Lack of resource tagging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without consistent tagging, Lambda functions cant be programmatically identified for ownership, environment, or purposehindering cost tracking, security policy enforcement, and operational oversight.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, uncontrolled automation, and rogue deployments.
  • Vectors:
    • CI/CD pipelines creating functions without required Environment or Owner tags.
    • Manual console creations that omit security or compliance tags.
    • Thirdparty tooling that doesnt enforce tagging standards.

Impacts

  • Visibility Gaps: Security teams cant quickly locate or audit sensitive functions.
  • Policy Evasion: Tagbased IAM or GuardDuty suppression rules fail to apply, allowing unauthorized access.
  • Cost Overruns: Untracked orphan functions incur unexpected charges.
  • Cleanup Challenges: Hard to identify and decommission unused or outdated functions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hidden Malicious Function: An attacker deploys a backdoor Lambda without Team or Project tagsescaping routine audits and persisting undetected.
  2. Policy Bypass: A compromised automation role creates a function lacking the Compliance=PCI tag, sidestepping strict IAM permissions tied to that tag.
  3. Orphaned Resources: A deprecated services Lambdas remain untagged; months later, they still run and bill but arent owned or monitored by any team.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data exposure at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data exposure at rest in AWS Lambda occurs when sensitive informationsuch as environment variables, function code packages, layers, or log snapshotsis stored unencrypted or with weak key management, making it accessible to unauthorized parties if storage systems are compromised.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised AWS credentials, and thirdparty service breaches.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Retrieving unencrypted Lambda environment variables or code bundles from S3/ECR.
    • Accessing /tmp storage on compromised execution hosts.
    • Downloading unencrypted CloudWatch log exports or Lambda layer artifacts.

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Exposed API keys, database passwords, or tokens.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of atrest encryption mandates (PCIDSS, HIPAA, GDPR).
  • Lateral Movement: Harvested credentials enable access to other AWS resources.
  • Reputational & Financial Damage: Data breach remediation costs and loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. ECR Artifact Theft: An attacker with ECR read permissions pulls a Lambda image containing hardcoded secrets in its code, extracting them offline.
  2. S3 Snapshot Breach: Misconfigured S3 bucket hosts unencrypted function packages; adversaries download and inspect code to harvest environment variables.
  3. Log Export Exposure: A support engineer exports CloudWatch logs (including sensitive payloads) to an unencrypted S3 bucket, which is later accessed by unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data interception in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data interception in transit occurs when communication to or from Lambda functionssuch as API Gateway requests, servicetoservice calls, or event payloadsis sent without proper TLS or through misconfigured network paths, allowing adversaries to eavesdrop on or alter the data stream.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Network eavesdroppers, maninthemiddle attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Invoking Lambda over HTTP (API Gateway or Function URL) instead of HTTPS
    • Misconfigured VPC endpoints or transit gateways that dont enforce encryption
    • Disabling or improperly validating TLS in SDKs or custom HTTP clients

Impacts

  • Credential Theft: API keys, JWTs, or signed URLs in request headers can be captured
  • Payload Exposure: Sensitive event data (PII, business logic) is readable in flight
  • Message Tampering: Intransit modification of inputs or outputs leads to corrupted processing
  • Replay Attacks: Captured invocations can be resent to trigger unauthorized function executions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. API Gateway Misuse: A functions URL endpoint is configured for HTTP only. An attacker on the same network sniffs request bodies containing user credentials and session tokens.
  2. VPC Endpoint Bypass: Lambda communicates with an internal service through a VPC endpoint that doesnt require TLS. A compromised EC2 instance in the VPC intercepts and logs unencrypted RPC calls.
  3. TLS Downgrade in SDK: A custom Python client disables certificate verification when calling a Lambda-backed API; an attacker performs a MITM attack to inject malicious payloads into the functions execution.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

threat.name: Unauthorized invocation via public resource policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly permissive Lambda resource policies (e.g. "Principal": "*") expose functions to anyone on the internet or any AWS account, allowing unauthorized parties to invoke them without credentials.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised thirdparty accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Resourcebased policies granting lambda:InvokeFunction to Principal: "*".
    • Crossaccount policies missing Condition: {"StringEquals": {"AWS:SourceAccount": ...}}.
    • Automated scanners discovering public ARNs and issuing invoke requests.

Impacts

  • Unauthenticated Execution: Attackers trigger functions at will, potentially running malicious logic.
  • Cost Overruns: Highvolume invocations rack up unexpected AWS charges.
  • Data Exposure & Tampering: Functions that read or write sensitive data can be abused to leak or corrupt information.
  • Downstream Disruption: Flooded event sources (queues, streams) or dependent services may be overwhelmed or fail.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Function Flood: An attacker discovers a public Lambda ARN and scripts thousands of InvokeFunction calls per minute, incurring heavy costs and throttling backend resources.
  2. CrossAccount Abuse: A partners account has open invocation rights; a malicious actor uses it to invoke a paymentprocessing Lambda with crafted payloads, creating fraudulent transactions.
  3. Data Leak via Unauthorized Payloads: A function tied to an S3 bucket runs on every invocation; by invoking it with custom payloads, an attacker tricks it into returning sensitive file contents in its response.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of audit logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda API calls (e.g., CreateFunction, UpdateFunctionCode, InvokeFunction) arent captured by CloudTrail or centralized logging, unauthorized or malicious activity goes unrecorded.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Malicious insiders or compromised roles making API calls
  • Automated tools invoking or updating functions without generating logs
  • Misconfigured CloudTrail trails or logdelivery failures

Impacts

  • Undetected Changes: Function code or configuration modifications arent noticed
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Incidents cant be reconstructed or attributed
  • Compliance Failures: Violation of auditlogging mandates (e.g., PCIDSS, HIPAA)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker updates a paymentprocessing Lambda to include malicious logic; without CloudTrail logs, the change isnt traced.
  2. A rogue script purges function versions via the SDK; absent audit entries, the deletions go unnoticed until failures occur.
  3. CloudTrail misconfiguration drops InvokeFunction records; a compromised role invokes backdoor functions repeatedly without alerting security teams.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Bootstrap backdoor persistence in custom runtimes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Custom runtimes in AWS Lambda rely on a 'bootstrap' file as their entry point, executed before reaching the handler. Without proper monitoring, this file can be manipulated to include malicious logic, enabling persistence across deployments.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers with access to deployment processes can modify the 'bootstrap' file to execute unauthorized activities, such as exfiltrating data, establishing backdoors, or altering runtime functionality.
Impacts
The compromise of the 'bootstrap' file can lead to unauthorized data access, persistent backdoors in the runtime environment, and stealthy modifications that evade detection during typical security reviews.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker with deployment privileges embeds malicious code into the 'bootstrap' file that exfiltrates sensitive data to an external server. Despite subsequent changes to the main handler logic, the hidden backdoor remains operational, continuing its activity undetected across multiple deployments.

reference.name: Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor (July 11, 2025)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1494 - Runtime Data Manipulation

threat.name: Code integrity compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Malicious alteration of Lambda function code or its dependenciesvia compromised build pipelines, direct edits, or tainted layersinjects unauthorized logic into your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD systems, supplychain attackers
  • Vectors: Backdoored build artifacts, console/API code edits, inclusion of malicious Lambda layers

Impacts

  • Unauthorized code execution under your functions IAM role
  • Data exfiltration or tampering of event payloads and backend resources
  • Lateral movement via calls to other AWS services
  • Reputational harm and remediation costs

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CI/CD Injection: An attacker hijacks the build server to insert a reverseshell payload into the deployment ZIP.
  2. Console Swap: A compromised admin replaces production handler code via the AWS Console, embedding dataexfiltration logic.
  3. Malicious Layer: A popular thirdparty layer bundles a cryptominer, which executes under your account when included.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution

component.name: Customer facility
component.desc: Customer facility where data validation and copy process occurs.

weakness.name: CWE-1120
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1120: Excessive Code Complexity The code is too complex, as calculated using a well-defined, quantitative measure.

weakness.name: CWE-1247
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1247: Improper Protection Against Voltage and Clock Glitches The device does not contain or contains incorrectly implemented circuitry or sensors to detect and mitigate voltage and clock glitches and protect sensitive information or software contained on the device.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-707
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-707: Improper Neutralization The product does not ensure or incorrectly ensures that structured messages or data are well-formed and that certain security properties are met before being read from an upstream component or sent to a downstream component.

weakness.name: CWE-91
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-91: XML Injection (aka Blind XPath Injection) The product does not properly neutralize special elements that are used in XML, allowing attackers to modify the syntax, content, or commands of the XML before it is processed by an end system. Within XML, special elements could include reserved words or characters such as "<", ">", """, and "&", which could then be used to add new data or modify XML syntax.

countermeasure.name: Enable autorun protection
countermeasure.desc:
Enabling Autorun protection is a critical security measure to prevent malicious software from automatically executing when a USB drive is connected to a system. This control mitigates the risks associated with unauthorized or harmful software spreading via the USB drive's autorun functionality, which attackers often exploit to deliver malware.

Disable Autorun Functionality:
This involves configuring systems to block the automatic execution of programs stored on USB drives. By disabling autorun features, organizations ensure that no executable files or scripts can run without explicit user approval, thereby reducing the risk of malware infections.

Use Security Policies:
Implement system-wide policies through operating systems or endpoint security tools to enforce Autorun protection. These policies should be applied consistently across all devices to ensure uniform protection against potential threats introduced via USB drives.

User Awareness and Training:
Educate users on the risks associated with Autorun functionality and the importance of scanning USB drives before accessing their contents. This ensures that users remain vigilant and do not inadvertently execute malicious software.

Reference:

  • Autorun Protection USB Drive

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity
SI-6 Security and Privacy Function Verification
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

customField.value: SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

countermeasure.name: Implement data access controls
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing data access controls for USB drives is a proactive security measure to restrict and monitor access to sensitive data. This ensures that only authorized users can access, modify, or transfer data on USB drives, reducing the risk of unauthorized data breaches and misuse.

Role-Based Access Controls (RBAC):
Define and enforce access permissions based on user roles. This ensures that only individuals with specific privileges can access or modify data on USB drives. For instance, administrators may have full access, while general users are limited to read-only permissions.

Encryption for Sensitive Data:
Require encryption for data stored on USB drives. Encrypted data ensures that even if the drive is lost or stolen, unauthorized individuals cannot access its contents without the decryption key.

Monitoring and Logging:
Implement logging mechanisms to record all access attempts and data transfers involving USB drives. Regularly review these logs to detect unauthorized activities or anomalies.

Device Authentication:
Use unique device IDs or certificates to ensure that only authorized USB drives can connect to the network. This prevents unauthorized or untrusted USB devices from accessing sensitive systems or data.

Reference:

  • Guide to protecting the confidentiality of Personally Identifiable Information (PII)

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

countermeasure.name: Implement USB device whitelisting
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing USB device whitelisting is a security measure designed to control and limit the USB devices that can connect to organizational systems. By allowing only pre-approved and trusted USB devices, this control mitigates risks associated with unauthorized access, data theft, and malware infections through USB drives.

Whitelist Authorized Devices:
Create a list of approved USB devices based on unique identifiers such as device IDs or serial numbers. This ensures only trusted devices can establish a connection, reducing the risk of unauthorized devices being used for malicious purposes.

Enforce Policy Through Security Tools:
Use endpoint security solutions or operating system policies to enforce whitelisting. These tools can automatically block unapproved USB devices while allowing seamless use of authorized ones, ensuring consistent compliance with security protocols.

Regularly Update and Review the Whitelist:
Periodically review and update the whitelist to include new devices and remove those that are no longer in use. This maintains the effectiveness of the control and minimizes potential vulnerabilities.

Audit and Monitoring:
Implement logging and monitoring of USB activity to detect attempts to connect unauthorized devices. Reviewing these logs can provide insights into potential threats and ensure policy adherence.

Reference:

  • Best Practice Guide: Making USB Ports Secure

countermeasure.name: Regularly update firmware
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly updating firmware for USB drives and connected devices is a critical security measure to ensure protection against vulnerabilities and maintain optimal functionality. Firmware updates address security flaws, improve device performance, and provide new features that enhance security and usability.

Apply Security Patches:
Ensure firmware updates include patches for known vulnerabilities. Keeping firmware up to date reduces the risk of exploitation by attackers leveraging outdated or flawed firmware.

Automate the Update Process:
Utilize centralized management tools to automate the deployment of firmware updates across all USB devices. Automation reduces the likelihood of missed updates and ensures consistency across the organization.

Verify Update Authenticity:
Confirm that firmware updates are downloaded from trusted sources and digitally signed by the manufacturer. This prevents the installation of malicious firmware during the update process.

Monitor for Vendor Updates:
Stay informed about firmware updates released by device manufacturers. Proactively monitor vendor announcements and apply updates promptly to minimize exposure to emerging threats.

Reference:

  • Guide to Enterprise Patch Management Technologies

countermeasure.name: Use surge protectors
countermeasure.desc:
Using surge protectors is a proactive security measure designed to safeguard USB drives and connected devices from power surges that can cause physical damage or data loss. Surge protectors regulate and stabilize electrical current, mitigating the risks associated with sudden voltage spikes.

Prevent Hardware Damage:
Surge protectors act as a barrier between USB devices and power sources, absorbing excess voltage caused by electrical surges. This prevents physical damage to USB drives and the systems they are connected to, ensuring hardware longevity.

Data Protection:
By preventing power-related damage, surge protectors reduce the risk of data corruption or loss on USB drives, preserving the integrity of critical information.

Protect Against Environmental Risks:
Use surge protectors with USB ports in environments prone to power fluctuations, such as those caused by lightning, power outages, or unstable electrical grids. These devices help maintain stable power delivery to connected USB hardware.

Compliance with Safety Standards:
Choose surge protectors certified by recognized safety organizations, ensuring they meet industry standards for effective protection against power surges.

Reference:

  • Guide to Industrial Control Systems (ICS) Security

countermeasure.name: Utilize data encryption
countermeasure.desc:
Utilizing data encryption on USB drives is a fundamental security measure to protect sensitive information from unauthorized access. Encryption converts data into a secure format, ensuring that only authorized users with the correct decryption key can access the content.

Encrypt Data on USB Drives:
Use strong encryption algorithms such as AES-256 to secure data stored on USB drives. Encrypting all files ensures that sensitive information remains protected, even if the drive is lost or stolen.

Password-Protected Access:
Pair encryption with password protection to ensure only authorized individuals can unlock and access encrypted data. This adds an additional layer of security to the encryption process.

Hardware Encryption:
Consider using USB drives with built-in hardware encryption. These devices automatically encrypt and decrypt data on the drive, simplifying the process and enhancing security without relying on external software.

Ensure Encryption Key Management:
Securely manage encryption keys to prevent unauthorized access. Use centralized key management solutions or ensure keys are stored securely and distributed only to authorized personnel.

Reference:

  • Guide to Protecting the Confidentiality of Personally Identifiable Information (PII)

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data theft
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data theft via USB drives involves the unauthorized access, copying, or extraction of sensitive information using USB storage devices. Attackers exploit the portability and ubiquity of USB drives to infiltrate systems and steal confidential data.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Malicious USB drives: Devices embedded with malware that execute upon connection.
  • Insiders with access: Authorized individuals misusing USB drives to exfiltrate data.
  • Lost or stolen USB drives: Unencrypted USBs falling into attackers' hands.
  • Public USB ports: Connecting compromised USBs in public areas.

Impacts

  • Confidential data exposure: Unauthorized access to sensitive information.
  • Financial losses: Costs from data breaches and remediation efforts.
  • Reputational damage: Loss of trust from customers and stakeholders.
  • Operational disruptions: Business interruptions while addressing breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Insider exfiltration: An employee copies confidential reports to a USB drive for unauthorized use.
  2. Lost USB device: A USB containing customer data is lost, allowing attackers to access the information.
  3. Malware-laden USB attack: Attackers leave infected USBs in public places; when connected, they steal data and compromise systems.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-114 - Peripheral Data Bus Interception

threat.name: Loss of data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Loss of data via USB drives involves the accidental or intentional disappearance of sensitive information stored on USB storage devices. This threat can arise from device failure, human error, theft, or malicious actions, leading to the permanent or temporary unavailability of critical data.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Human error: Accidental deletion or formatting of USB drives by users.
  • Device failure: Hardware malfunctions that result in data corruption or loss.
  • Theft or loss: Unauthorized individuals gaining access to lost or stolen USB drives containing sensitive information.
  • Malware: Malicious software that corrupts or deletes data stored on USB devices.

Impacts

  • Data unavailability: Critical information becomes inaccessible, hindering business operations.
  • Financial losses: Costs associated with data recovery, downtime, and potential fines for non-compliance with data protection regulations.
  • Reputational damage: Loss of trust from customers and stakeholders due to compromised data integrity.
  • Operational disruptions: Interruptions in workflows and productivity while addressing data loss issues.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Accidental deletion: An employee mistakenly formats a USB drive containing important project files, resulting in the loss of critical data.
  2. Device failure: A USB drive malfunctions, corrupting stored financial records and disrupting accounting processes.
  3. Theft and unauthorized access: A lost USB drive is found by an unauthorized individual who accesses and disseminates confidential client information.
  4. Malware-induced data loss: A user connects an infected USB drive to their computer, causing malware to delete essential documents stored on the device.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-408 - Unencrypted Sensitive Data Communication

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: USB device spoofing
threat.desc:
General threat description
USB device spoofing involves attackers impersonating legitimate USB devices to deceive systems and users. By mimicking trusted hardware, malicious actors can gain unauthorized access, deliver malware, or exfiltrate data, compromising the security and integrity of connected systems.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Malicious USB devices: Devices designed to appear as legitimate peripherals (e.g., keyboards, storage drives) but contain hidden malicious functionalities.
  • Insiders with access: Authorized individuals who introduce spoofed USB devices into secure environments.
  • Public USB ports: Untrusted USB connections in public areas that attackers exploit to connect spoofed devices.
  • Supply chain attacks: USB devices tampered with during manufacturing or distribution to include spoofing capabilities.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access: Attackers can bypass security controls by presenting spoofed devices as trusted hardware.
  • Malware installation: Spoofed USB devices can deliver and install malicious software on connected systems.
  • Data exfiltration: Impersonated storage devices can transfer sensitive data to unauthorized locations.
  • System compromise: Manipulation of system settings or functionalities through spoofed input devices.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Office infiltration: An attacker plugs a spoofed USB keyboard into a company computer, executing commands to steal sensitive data.
  2. Public charging station exploit: A user connects their device to a compromised public USB port, unknowingly installing malware from a spoofed USB drive.
  3. Supply chain compromise: USB flash drives distributed to employees are pre-configured to act as network adapters, allowing attackers to intercept network traffic.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-119 - Latent Hardware Debug Port Allows Memory/Code Manipulation

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Malware infection
threat.desc:
General threat description
Malware infection via USB drives involves the introduction of malicious software into a system through USB storage devices. Attackers exploit the physical accessibility and ubiquity of USB drives to infiltrate systems, install malware, and compromise the security and functionality of connected computers and networks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Malicious USB drives: USB devices embedded with malware that automatically execute upon connection.
  • Insiders with access: Authorized individuals who intentionally insert infected USB drives into systems.
  • Public USB ports: Untrusted USB connections in public areas used to deliver malware when devices are connected.
  • Supply chain attacks: USB drives tampered with during manufacturing or distribution to include malicious software.

Impacts

  • System compromise: Installation of malware can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and control over affected systems.
  • Data theft: Sensitive information can be stolen, including personal data, financial records, and intellectual property.
  • Operational disruptions: Malware can cause system crashes, loss of functionality, and interruptions in business operations.
  • Financial losses: Costs related to remediation, data recovery, downtime, and potential regulatory fines.
  • Reputational damage: Loss of trust from customers, partners, and stakeholders due to compromised data security.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Office espionage: An employee inserts a malicious USB drive into a company computer, installing ransomware that encrypts critical business data.
  2. Public hotspot exploit: A user connects their laptop to a compromised public USB charging station, unknowingly downloading spyware that monitors their online activities.
  3. Supply chain compromise: USB flash drives distributed to employees are pre-infected with malware, allowing attackers to infiltrate the corporate network once connected.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-224 - Excessive Access via Software Diagnostic Features

threat.name: Power surge damage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Power surge damage involves unexpected spikes in electrical power that can harm USB drives. These surges may result from lightning strikes, power outages, or fluctuations in the electrical grid, leading to physical damage to the USB drives circuitry. Such damage can render the USB drive inoperable, cause data loss, or compromise the integrity of stored information.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Electrical grid fluctuations: Variations in power supply causing voltage spikes that affect USB devices connected to powered systems.
  • Lightning strikes: Direct or nearby lightning events inducing power surges that damage connected USB drives.
  • Power outages and restorations: Sudden loss and restoration of power leading to voltage instability that can harm USB devices.
  • Faulty power supplies: Poor-quality or malfunctioning power sources failing to regulate voltage, resulting in surges.

Impacts

  • Data loss: Corruption or destruction of data stored on the USB drive, leading to the loss of important information.
  • Device failure: Physical damage to the USB drives hardware, making it unusable and requiring replacement.
  • Operational disruption: Interruptions in business activities due to the unavailability of essential data stored on damaged USB drives.
  • Financial losses: Costs associated with data recovery, replacing damaged USB drives, and potential downtime affecting productivity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Office lightning strike: A lightning strike during a storm causes a power surge that damages USB drives connected to computers, resulting in the loss of critical project files.
  2. Power restoration surge: After a power outage, the sudden return of electricity causes a voltage spike that corrupts data on USB storage devices used by employees.
  3. Faulty power supply: A companys unregulated power supply leads to frequent surges that wear out USB drives over time, causing repeated data loss and hardware failures.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-101 - Power Consumption Analysis Side Channel

threat.name: Firmware attacks
threat.desc:
General threat description
Firmware attacks on USB drives involve unauthorized modifications to the devices firmware, allowing attackers to alter functionality, install malware, or compromise connected systems. By tampering with firmware, attackers can create persistent threats that activate whenever the USB drive is connected.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Malicious insiders: Authorized individuals who modify firmware to embed malware.
  • Remote attackers: Exploiting vulnerabilities to inject malicious code during firmware updates.
  • Supply chain compromises: Tampering with USB drives during manufacturing or distribution.

Impacts

  • Persistent malware: Malware remains on the USB drive even after reformatting.
  • Unauthorized access: Attackers gain elevated privileges on connected systems.
  • Data exfiltration: Sensitive data is stolen without detection.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Supply chain compromise: Pre-infected USB drives install spyware when connected to company computers.
  2. Insider threat: An employee modifies a USB drives firmware to create a backdoor for system access.
  3. Remote injection: An attacker exploits firmware update flaws to insert malicious code into USB drives.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-211 - Device Allows Unauthenticated Firmware Installation

weakness.name: CWE-308 CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required. CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319 CWE-354 CWE-311
weakness.desc:
CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.
CWE-354: Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or "checksums" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission. Improper validation of checksums before use results in an unnecessary risk that can easily be mitigated. The protocol specification describes the algorithm used for calculating the checksum. It is then a simple matter of implementing the calculation and verifying that the calculated checksum and the received checksum match. Improper verification of the calculated checksum and the received checksum can lead to far greater consequences. CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-453
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-453: Insecure Default Variable Initialization The product, by default, initializes an internal variable with an insecure or less secure value than is possible.

weakness.name: CWE-77
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-77: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command ('Command Injection') The product constructs all or part of a command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended command when it is sent to a downstream component.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-829
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-829: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere The product imports, requires, or includes executable functionality (such as a library) from a source that is outside of the intended control sphere.

countermeasure.name: Enforce input validation and sanitization
countermeasure.desc:
Identify All Inputs:

  • Catalog all points where data is received, including user forms, API endpoints, query parameters, and file uploads.

Define Input Rules:

  • Determine acceptable data types, formats, and ranges for each input. For example:
    • Numbers should fall within specified ranges.
    • Strings must conform to allowed character sets or patterns (e.g., email addresses).
    • Files should only have specific, allowed MIME types.

Implement Server-Side Validation:

  • Check Types and Formats: Use strict checks for data types, lengths, and formats using regular expressions or parsing functions.
  • Range Checking: Ensure numeric inputs fall within valid ranges and string lengths are bounded.
  • Required Fields: Confirm required fields are provided and contain valid data.

Sanitize Inputs:

  • Escape Special Characters: Escape or encode characters to neutralize code injection risks. For example, escape HTML entities or use parameterized SQL queries.
  • Strip Invalid Characters: Remove unwanted characters, whitespace, or control characters that don't meet the expected input format.

Reject Invalid Inputs:

  • Return clear error messages with an appropriate HTTP status code (e.g., 400 Bad Request) while ensuring sensitive details are not exposed.

Client-Side Validation (Supplementary):

  • Implement client-side validation for a better user experience but never rely on it exclusively for security purposes.

Input Logging and Monitoring:

  • Log suspicious inputs or repeated validation failures for further analysis.
  • Monitor these logs to identify potential attack attempts or input pattern changes.

Regular Security Reviews:

  • Review and update validation rules based on changing business logic or new threat models.
  • Conduct code reviews and penetration testing focused on injection vulnerabilities.

These actions will ensure input validation and sanitization protect against common injection vulnerabilities, enhancing the overall security posture.

reference.name: OWASP Injection Prevention Cheat Sheet
Secure Coding Practices

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK ICS - M0818 - Validate Program Inputs

countermeasure.name: Ensure comprehensive data protection measures
countermeasure.desc:
In today's digital landscape, protecting sensitive data against tampering and unauthorized access is paramount for maintaining its integrity and confidentiality. Implementing Comprehensive Data Protection Measures is critical to achieving this goal. These measures encompass a variety of techniques designed to secure data at every stage of its lifecycle. Here's how developers can effectively implement these data protection strategies:

  1. Ensuring Data Integrity with Cryptographic Hashes: Utilize cryptographic hashing algorithms (e.g., SHA-256) to generate a unique hash value for your data. This hash acts as a digital fingerprint, allowing any alteration of the data to be easily detected. Hashing is vital for verifying data integrity during transmission or storage.
  2. Utilizing Digital Signatures: Digital signatures provide a means to verify the authenticity and integrity of data. By signing data with a private key and allowing verification with the corresponding public key, you can ensure that data has not been tampered with and confirm its origin.
  3. Applying Strong Encryption:
    • Data at Rest: Encrypt sensitive data stored on persistent media using robust encryption standards like AES-256. This protects the data against unauthorized access if the storage medium is compromised.
    • Data in Transit: Use protocols like TLS/SSL to encrypt data during transmission over networks. This prevents data from being intercepted and read by unauthorized parties.
  4. Key Management: Implement secure key management practices to protect encryption keys. This includes storing keys in a dedicated hardware security module (HSM), using key rotation policies, and ensuring that keys are accessible only to authorized applications and users.
  5. Regular Security Audits: Conduct periodic security audits and vulnerability assessments to identify and address potential weaknesses in your data protection measures. This includes reviewing encryption protocols, access controls, and compliance with relevant security standards.

By adopting these comprehensive data protection measures, developers can significantly enhance the security of sensitive data within the Data Processing Component. These practices not only help in protecting data from external threats but also bolster trust in the system's ability to safeguard valuable information.

reference.name: Best Practices for Data Protection

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive security configuration and vulnerability management
countermeasure.desc:
Inventory Assets: Compile an up-to-date list of all hardware, software, operating systems, and network devices used in the system. Include versions and configurations for each asset.

Baseline Configurations:

  • Establish secure baseline configurations for each asset type based on industry best practices (e.g., CIS Benchmarks).
  • Disable or remove unnecessary services, ports, and software to minimize attack surface.

Configuration Management:

  • Policies: Create a strict policy outlining approved changes to configurations.
  • Version Control: Use a version control system to track configuration changes.
  • Monitoring: Continuously monitor configurations for unauthorized changes and alert administrators.

Patch Management:

  • Automated Updates: Enable automated updates where feasible, particularly for high-risk software and services.
  • Manual Patching: Create a regular patching schedule for critical vulnerabilities that require manual intervention.
  • Testing: Test patches in a staging environment before deploying to production.

Vulnerability Scanning:

  • Use automated tools to regularly scan the entire system for known vulnerabilities.
  • Prioritize vulnerabilities based on criticality and exposure level, and assign remediation timelines accordingly.

Penetration Testing:

  • Conduct regular penetration testing to uncover vulnerabilities not covered by automated scans.
  • Engage third-party testers to validate internal security assumptions.

Incident Response Plan:

  • Develop and document procedures for responding to security incidents stemming from misconfigurations or unpatched vulnerabilities.
  • Train teams on identifying and reacting to incidents efficiently.

Auditing and Reporting:

  • Maintain detailed logs of configuration changes, vulnerability scans, and patch deployments.
  • Audit regularly to ensure compliance with internal policies and external regulations.

Continuous Improvement:

  • Periodically review configuration baselines and update them to accommodate new threats or industry guidelines.
  • Incorporate findings from incident reports into improved security practices.

These steps will ensure that configurations remain secure and vulnerabilities are swiftly managed, reducing exposure to emerging threats.

reference.name: Guide to Secure Configuration
Vulnerability Management

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1016 - Vulnerability Scanning||ATT&CK Enterprise - M1022 - Restrict File and Directory Permissions

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting and traffic analysis
countermeasure.desc:
Identify Traffic Sources:

  • Analyze and categorize typical traffic sources, like client IP addresses or API keys, and determine which should be subject to rate limiting. Examples include web clients, internal services, and third-party applications.

Establish Rate Limiting Policies:

  • Define Limits: Set rate limits based on endpoint criticality and business requirements. Common metrics include requests per second, per minute, or per hour.
  • Granularity: Apply limits to specific IP addresses, API keys, user accounts, or other identifiers as appropriate.

Choose Implementation Strategy:

  • Server-Side Limiting: Implement rate limiting at the application level through middleware, frameworks, or server modules like NGINX.
  • Third-Party Solutions: Use cloud or third-party services like AWS API Gateway or Cloudflare to manage traffic limits externally.

Integrate Traffic Analysis:

  • Logging: Log traffic metadata, including source IPs, URLs, and request timestamps.
  • Monitoring Tools: Use monitoring tools to visualize traffic patterns, detect anomalies, and trigger alerts on suspicious spikes.
  • Traffic Baseline: Establish baselines for "normal" traffic patterns to help identify deviations.

Throttling and Blocking:

  • Throttling: Gracefully throttle traffic exceeding the defined limit, returning HTTP status code 429 (Too Many Requests) or similar.
  • Blocking: Temporarily or permanently block clients that continually violate rate limits.

Alerting and Incident Management:

  • Configure alerts to notify the security team when rate limits are breached.
  • Document procedures to handle and investigate incidents involving abuse or potential attacks.

Feedback Loop:

  • Review logs, alerts, and traffic analysis reports to refine rate limiting thresholds over time.
  • Use traffic data to enhance the understanding of user behavior and detect emerging attack patterns.

These steps will help you minimize the risk of service abuse while ensuring legitimate traffic remains uninterrupted.

reference.name: OWASP Rate Limiting

PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained

countermeasure.name: Implement secure software supply chain management
countermeasure.desc:
Inventory and Catalog:

  • Identify all software components, dependencies, and third-party libraries in your supply chain, including open-source and proprietary software.
  • Maintain an up-to-date inventory of software versions and configurations.

Select Trusted Sources:

  • Download libraries, tools, and dependencies only from trusted, verified sources (e.g., official vendor sites or verified package managers like npm, Maven, or PyPI).
  • Verify checksums or digital signatures when available.

Assess Security Risks:

  • Perform security assessments of third-party vendors and libraries to identify known vulnerabilities or questionable practices.
  • Implement policies for onboarding new vendors, emphasizing adherence to secure coding standards.

Integrate Scanning and Testing:

  • Static Analysis: Use static code analysis tools to scan source code for vulnerabilities.
  • Dependency Scanning: Automate scanning for known vulnerabilities in dependencies using tools like OWASP Dependency-Check or Snyk.
  • Dynamic Testing: Conduct dynamic application security testing (DAST) to uncover runtime vulnerabilities.

Patch Management:

  • Stay updated on security advisories and vulnerability databases (e.g., CVE database, NVD).
  • Promptly apply patches or updates to third-party libraries, frameworks, and tools.

Control the Build Environment:

  • Isolate the build environment to reduce exposure to unauthorized access.
  • Ensure integrity by using reproducible builds with tools like Docker or Buildpacks.
  • Sign your builds and verify signatures at each stage to detect tampering.

Implement Access Controls:

  • Enforce least-privilege access to build servers, version control systems, and package repositories.
  • Regularly review permissions for contractors or external contributors.

Monitor and Respond:

  • Monitor for suspicious activity in the build environment, such as unauthorized access or unexpected changes.
  • Develop an incident response plan tailored to supply chain attacks, emphasizing quick containment and recovery.

Supply Chain Policies:

  • Establish and enforce policies around third-party software usage, including requirements for licensing, version control, and regular security reviews.
  • Educate development teams on supply chain risks and secure coding practices.

These steps will help ensure the integrity of your software supply chain and minimize the risk of malicious or compromised components.

reference.name: Configuration Management Best Practices
Supply Chain Risk Management

countermeasure.name: Strengthen authentication and access control
countermeasure.desc:
Authentication Methods:

  • Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Enable MFA for all users to add an extra layer of security beyond just passwords. Common factors include TOTP (Google Authenticator) or hardware tokens (YubiKey).
  • Single Sign-On (SSO): Integrate with an SSO provider to centralize authentication and reduce reliance on multiple passwords.
  • Password Policies: Enforce strong password policies such as minimum length, complexity requirements, and periodic password rotation.

Access Controls:

  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Assign permissions based on user roles to minimize the exposure of sensitive functions and data.
  • Least Privilege: Ensure that users have only the minimum necessary permissions to perform their tasks. Review and revoke excessive privileges regularly.

Authentication Protocols:

  • Use secure authentication protocols like OAuth2, SAML, or OpenID Connect for web services.
  • Ensure all data transfers during authentication are encrypted (e.g., via TLS/SSL).

Session Management:

  • Implement secure session management to prevent session hijacking and fixation:
    • Use secure cookies (HTTPOnly and Secure flags) to store session tokens.
    • Regenerate session tokens upon authentication and privilege escalation.
    • Set session expiration times and inactivity logout.

Account Lockout and Recovery:

  • Implement automatic account lockout after repeated failed login attempts to prevent brute force attacks.
  • Provide secure account recovery options, such as email or SMS verification, ensuring that recovery information is validated and updated.

Logging and Monitoring:

  • Log authentication attempts, password changes, and privilege escalations for auditing purposes.
  • Monitor access patterns and trigger alerts for suspicious activities, such as repeated login failures or sudden privilege changes.

Regular Audits and Reviews:

  • Conduct regular audits of user accounts and roles to ensure compliance with access control policies.
  • Review logs and monitoring alerts to identify and investigate unusual behavior.

Security Education:

  • Train users on secure authentication practices, like recognizing phishing attacks and maintaining strong, unique passwords.

Implementing these measures will significantly reduce unauthorized access risks and strengthen overall authentication security.

reference.name: NIST Guide to MFA
